reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overgrowth. The game about bunnies and various other animals battling it out to prevent becoming a massive red mess of liquid and to feel the pain the usual ragdoll physic.

As Overgrowth is currently still in early alpha and has been for a few years, a structured story still hasn't been implemented BUT the current 'challenges' keep you feeling amused and entertained. The main appeal about this game is the combat system (the best of any game I've ever witnessed). Every single encounter provides something new and makes you feel like a complete baddass if you are provided with a victory. The maps feel fresh and different and the in-game editor provides hours and hours of extra interest.

BUY THIS NOW.

(The steam game time doesn't represent what I've played, I've had it for around two years (as of Dec 2013) and I've probably stuck around 150 hours or so into the game as it wasn't on steam before.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overgrowth is a third person action game where you get to play as giant rabbits, rats, wolves and more fighting against other rabbits, rats, wolves and more. The game's main selling point is it's brutal combat which is best witnessed in the arena where you are automatically pitted against enemies either with your bare hands or with one of the game's few weapons. If you don't want to play the arena you can wander around one of the game's other maps and if you wish you can even spawn in enemies to take on. Despite all of these features the game has one glaring issue which completely changes whether or not you should buy this game.

+Great graphics
+Brutal and enjoyable combat
+You can slow down time
+Good controls
+Maps are quite nice and reasonably large
+If you play on the arena you are automatically put in to teams (or not) to fight other enemies and you are equipped with weapons automatically
+A number of different species you can play as
+There are different challenges for you to complete
+Good physics
+Decent modding community
+Good platforming mechanics

-This game has been in Alpha since 2008 and it's currently on build 209, updates are few and far between and offer nothing more than bug fixes, they do not add any more ways to keep you playing and more importantly they still haven't added the campaign modes which were promised
-Gets very repetitive very quickly
-Horribly overpriced considering what you get
-The game's platforming mechanics are wasted on the maps that are currently available, i.e. they're very flat maps or easy to get around
-Frequent crashes
-Long loading times

Verdict:
Do not buy this game.

It's a wonderful concept but I don't think the execution could be much worse and with it's current price tag and considering it's effectively just a tech demo with little to do you'd be wasting your money on a project that has been in Alpha for 7 years and is likely to remain in Alpha for the next 7 years.

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: To clarify things, I owned Overgrowth a year before it came out on Steam; my Steam playtime is irrelevant.

I make a point not to review games that are in alpha or beta until they're released, but I'll make an exception for Overgrowth for two simple reasons: (1) it's good enough to justify a $30 purchase even in its alpha builds, and (2) I consider it to be an absolutely enormous leap in the slow evolution of fighting games.

When you preorder Overgrowth, you get immediate access to the current alpha build, so you can test everything out right away as the developers add stuff. This alleviates the usual problem with preordering games, that is, putting down money for a product that doesn't exist yet.

The game itself currently boasts some of the smoothest, most fun, most intense combat of any game, ever, and I don't say that lightly. Overgrowth, like many indie games, uses physics as a driving mechanic. When you get kicked, your character reacts dynamically with a blend of animation and ragdoll. When you get stabbed, likewise. Dealing kicks and punches and slashes feels incredibly good -- the combat is fast-paced and frantic. Against more than one opponent, you'll almost inevitably lose unless your opponents are significantly slower or weaker than you, especially in a weapon fight.

Let's talk about weapon combat for a moment: it's just as fast as the unarmed combat, maybe even faster in the case of the fencing swords and knives. It's one or two hits to a kill, so blocking and dodging is absolutely essential. The fights are cinematic and extremely satisfying (this applies to unarmed fights as well), especially if you hit the slow-motion key (currently tab by default) just as either combatant dies.

The parkour can't go without mention. Though at this point in the game's development, the parkour is its weakest point (momentum doesn't carry while climbing), it's still ahead of many games with parkour elements. Wall-running, wall-jumping, and movement in genreral feel great. Everything flows together without the need for extraneous button-pressing, and when you do press a button, the resulting blended animation is a pleasure to watch. The only bad thing about the parkour, climbing, still isn't bad at all. It's still faster than most games, and still feels better than most games.

I can't recommend Overgrowth enough. You could buy it for the combat alone (setting aside that there's going to be an actual story, with the writer's skill already demonstrated in a full-length comic over at Wolfire's home page). Overgrowth's combat, in my opinion, is the most fun of any melee combat game ever made.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In development for seven years and still not complete. Wait for the overgrowth GOTY in 10 years.

EDIT: Okay some people are a little angry that i'm not giving the game enough credit, because after all it's only one person working on it and they made a whole new game engine, but they did not make it from scratch, which good for them. Here's the problem, they're too ambitious they chose to keep improving the engine over actually making the game fun. When I purchased this game 2 years ago I assumed it would hit beta in one year, because that's how the development looked like it was going.

Here's the thing is it feels like an advanced proof of concept, compared to a EA game like Prison Architect which has a lot of things to do inside it. The game has cool parkour, and interesting fighting mechanics but it's had that since 2011 and even with its interesting mechanics the game will keep you engaged for a couple hours and that's if you install mods.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the longest time, Broforce was my most played PC indie, but I think it's safe to say Overgrowth has supplanted that as my go-to game.

Now Overgrowth isn't complete by a long shot. It's still lacking a real campaign or story and the available content consists of a few challenges, several maps ranging from parkour-friendly courses to open areas with enemies to an arena. There's a robust level editor and a growing library of user content.

But that's not what makes Overgrowth so fun, so addicting, and challenging. In my opinion, gameplay itself is paramount to making or breaking a game, and Overgrowth delivers in spades. The combat is up there with Arkham Asylum as my favorite fighting system in a game, simple to control yet complex in its execution and endlessly satisfying to watch. From agile evasion to smooth judo counters to tense knife fights or rolling under a swinging blade and digging a spear into an enemy's chest, the combat is just glorious fun

The movement alone offers some of the best 3D platforming I've played since Prince of Persia in 2003. You're fast and insanely maneuverable, able to jump huge distances, wall run with ease, bounce between walls and roll under obstacles. Speed running through the community parkour maps is so entertaining.

But Overgrowth isn't just great in its execution, but as a whole package inside and out. The anthropomorphic animal warriors and the semi-realistic atmosphere bring to mind classics like Redwall and Watership Down, and the brutality only cements those associations. A fight isn't just a simple exchange of blows; blades and hard hits leave bloody wounds across the body, blood that drips and stains in physics-accurate patterns. Fatal impacts against hard surfaces are accompanied by crunching bone. A stealthy neck slice sends arterial spray everywhere. A tough fight leaves you bloody and battered. Dodge at the wrong time and a kick will impact your head with a tangible sense of weight and momentum. It's these aspects that make the game such an enjoyable experience

But there's more to come, from the proper integration of species like dogs, rats, and cats, and a full story. The backstory of the world has already been fleshed out in Lugaru and this fascinating digital comic (http://www.wolfire.com/comic#1) and if the game's story is as engrossing as the stories in those pages, Overgrowth could truly be the Redwall of gaming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can applaud Wolfire's ambition, and I appreciate that they bundle Receiver---which is a wonderful little bite-sized FPS---with Overgrowth, but that doesn't do much to offset two very key facts:

-Overgrowth is still in alpha, and a buggy alpha at that.
-It has been in alpha since 2008. SIX WHOLE YEARS.

I realize Wolfire is a very small studio, but thirty dollars for a buggy alpha is an extremely bad deal. They're at least transparent that it's an alpha, but I bought the game years ago before it was Greenlighted on Steam never even imagining that they would take this ridiculously long.

If you want to give Wolfire your money, go ahead. But keep in mind that this is nowhere NEAR a complete game---it's basically only a level editor/modkit and some assets at this point---and it's not clear when, if ever, a beta and/or a complete game will be forthcoming.

I recommend just buying Receiver instead. It's finished, it's cheap, it's interesting, and overall not only is it more bang for your buck but it still supports Wolfire.

If Wolfire learns some better time management skills and gets things moving, I may rewrite this review after sampling new features and content. Until then, this is a bad deal, and an example of the shortcomings of both Steam Greenlight and, to a greater extent, the whole concept of 'early access' in game sales.

EDIT: Before anyone gets snarky, I bought this game through Wolfire's website some time before it ever came to Steam. Also, I play games on a laptop, so sometimes I play games more than the time played record indicates. Now if you're going to make sarcastic comments at me, at least say something productive instead of trying to punch holes in my review, especially given that I at least tried to be fair.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really, really want to like this project. I want to say it has a bright future. The physics, the combat, the game engine itself, the platforming, are all *very* promising.  Unfortunately, in it's current state it simply (to me) not worth the backing cost at all.

Lately I've looked at my library, and I'm glad to say that out of all my titles, I regret very few purchases. Unfortunately, Overgrowth is a backing that for me is starting to look worthy of seeking a refund for. The speed of updates, the years it's been in development, and the.. state of the game/engine itself, (which grants me a low frame rate and crashes regardless of my settings, [important to note, I can run and enjoy GTAV and BF4 on this machine] even now), bring the centrally poised thumb downward.

I won't say don't support them. And I am not yet decided on whether I would seek a refund with Wolfire Games.  I believe they are honest and don't spend the funds they receive wrongly necessarily, but I also can't say I think this price is worth what is offered. If this game does come to fruition within the next 1-2 decades, I'm sure it would be a great game, with a great engine, physics, combat based on said physics, and maybe an interesting story and (possibly?) multiplayer.

As of now, you are putting your faith, and money, into a product which, (for some reason I personally cannot run very well at all), is ultimately far from finished and contains very little replay value in my view.

That said, when/if this title is *ever* finished or near finished, I imagine it would certainly be worth this price, if not more.

Early Access Review

If smacking someone in the face with a machinegun of some sort doesn't do it for you in games, then this is the game for you!  It's not a game where you click and the game plays a hit animation for whatever you clicked.  In this game, your character basically becomes a physics object and the force will actually transfer to your opponent ( e.g. if you roundhouse someone, they will go FLYING in the opposite direction (unless they blocked, in which case, awww too bad)).
Oh, there's also parkour.
And mods.
And maps.
And a forum.
and a community-created mod browser.
Ok go buy it now.

P.S.  It isn't a furry game,  nor is Lugaru.  Apparently, David thought it would be too brutal on humans and with rabbits, the jumps and what not are more realistic.  And the combat is pretty brutal.
Oh, and there's instakilling wolves.  And weapons.
Ok seriously now go buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This awesome game is about rabbits brutally stabbing each other to death with various weapons and/or beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of each other with their bare hands. The combat system is probably the most intense and fast paced I've ever seen. This game also has some of my favorite fighting mechanics in any fighting game, ever. The rabbits and other animals move blindingly fast, and attack unrelentingly, with each single move possibly ending in death. If Tony Jaa was a rabbit he would be in this game. It's like my dream Redwall game but totally not for kids(although those books were pretty damn violent). The graphics are aesthetically pleasing, but the really impressive part is the near perfect animation of the characters. They move so freakin'  fast that it's hard to appreciate all the work that's gone into animating these animals, but when viewed in slow motion (available at any time by pressing tab) you'll see each character inflict gruesome wounds on each other and block/ dodge in a convincing dance of death. When you see detailed blood streams running down your rabbit avatar's face and dripping onto the cold snow after a gruesome fight you'll see what I mean.

I played the alpha for this a bit prior to the steam release and while there's not really anything concrete to do yet I'm super excited to see where this goes. There's plenty of user created maps and stuff to mess around in too. Unfortunately the game kind of comes off as an early tech demo but so far the combat and parkour elements are super fun by themselves.

This game is a sequel to Lugaru HD, which came out quite a long time ago but featured the same peculiar rabbit on rabbit combat. The creator is Wolfire Games, who were responsible for organizing the first Humble Bundle. They deserve your money just for creating such an amazingly affordable method of pc game distribution while giving so much to charity!

You should probably get this if you have any interest in a brutal fast paced fighting game. Any game which lets you run up the side of the wall, do a backflip, and slam your giant rabbit feet into someone's face is certainly worth a look.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to admit, my hopes were set way too high when I bought this game. I assumed that it was going to have open worlds with differently dispersed enemies and weapons, as well as open-world style gameplay. When I got in-game, I found the Start menu to be extremely simplistic, which, in my opinion, is a good way to navigate easily. As I entered Campaign mode, I was thrown off by not one campaign with open-world gameplay, but 3, with set objectives for each. After discovering that I could not play 2 of the campaigns, I chose Gladiator, which forces you to fight for an infinite amount of time with infinite amounts of matches. Once in-game, I found it to be extremely buggy, with simple combat controls (LMB is the only way to attack). The graphics were alright, however, I found it annoying that the most common attack is a kick. Soon, the controls made more sense. I discovered how to duck and roll around like a wheel. Countering was difficult, but fun. The enemies were ridiculously difficult to defeat, but I got a 'kick' out of the ragdoll of their bodies and cheapshotting the other rabbits by throwing spears at them as soon as the match starts. Eventually, I found that you could revive all rabbits, including yourself, by simply hitting X. I used this to stay in the matches, even after I had died. Soon came the 'Lightning Key', as I called it, which allows your rabbit to send out a lightning bolt from his chest, instantly killing all other rabbits. I used this to get my skillset up to well over 2000. I had over 4 quadrillion fans, and my rabbit's apparel was completely black. The enemies were bugged by this point, being larger than the building itself, and simply put, a large mass of glitched black. They were impossible to defeat, and could kick me infinite distances. I crashed the game 4 times before I gave up this cheating lifestyle and moved on to beat all of the challenge missions, which, surprisingly, were ridiculously easy. This whole review may seem like I'm bashing on this game, but that is not the case.

I had a lot of fun with this game. I got Receiver with it, which I still actively play. I waited ever since I got Steam to get this game, so it was a relief when I finally played it for the first time. The countless bugs and glitches make this game awfully fun, and I think it has quite a bit of potential, once it actually gets out of Alpha.

10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOvergrowth is an amazing game as it stands. Even as a game just getting off the ground it shows features many triple A titles seem to leave out. The AI is better than most, the physics and damage system is revolutionary, and above all it is a truly fun and enjoyable game ! When it comes to gameplay there are a few quirks, bugs can appear from time to time, and preformance is fairly limited even on beastly Pc's. But these are things we can expect from a game still in Beta. And besides that the gameplay is outstanding both un-armed and armed combat is a blast and doesnt take too long to get used to. From massive AI battles to one on one areana matches you cant stop having fun with this game. In my opinion if your looking for a fun fighting based game its a must have if not its still something you should either buy or keep your eye on this game keeps on showing a lot of potential.

Early Access Review

This game is solid for an early access. The title has earned a special place in our scam list, and most would agree that the number of devs that abuse the system are enormous. However, after a long period of stagnant development, the devs have come back, and fequent updates seem to have come back.

Is the price of 30USD waaay too much? Yes. At it's current stage of development, I'd say 10-15 is a much, much better price. I'd recommend waiting until it's on sale for at least 50% off. That way, you don't feel like you're risking too much on a game that, as always, could just stop being updated forever.

It's more of an arcade game at the moment. It's fun to play occationally, messing around with the weapons and parkour mechanics. Get it at a good price, and you shouldn't feel ripped off. Summer sales, ho!

Early Access Review

Having preordered long before steam keys were released, I have more time in the game than steam says.

Despite it's long time in alpha (yes, steam calls it Early access, but keep in mind this game was pre-purchaseable long before steam had an early access system in place) I still am looking forward to the finished product. I have been following the video logs a long time and am always impressed with the technical achievements they showcase.

There are simply no other combat brawling games like this. If you can pull it off, you can deliver blows that break bone, a slash with a blade will maim or kill your opponent realistically, the detail put into the animation that makes for a fluid visual spectacle. It's fast paced and you have to develop skills and quick reflexes but I have never played a more satisfying fighting game.

Early Access Review

God damnit!

I really wanted to give this game a good review but the updates are far too slow to be released and even worse is that the updates are just some patches. There hasn't been major changes or even new content in two years.

But lets go back to my history with the game,
Back in the day (two years ago) the game was on a website, updates would come out once every week or so and new content was added some of those weeks, then roughly a year later the game gets released on steam. Yay! The people who bought the game on the website got a code for the new steam release. After the game gets released on steam people expected a major inprovement on the engine? maybe the graphics? oh and what about the combat? but nope, it was just another version of the game on steam. updates still kept coming out every week but all the updates about new content had and still have stopped and updates felt more like crappy patches than anything, the game kept crashing for no reason and I would be able to understand this because it's Early Access, and we all know that Early Access games arn't going to be bug free, but if the game keeps crashing for two years and the developer hasn't did anything about it? I really can't understand that. even if the developer would have released an update every three days it would still feel cheap.

So that's why im giving this game a negitive review, it was such a shame as I like the idea of a third person parkour, action game, the parkour even felt amazing when you mastered it and the combat was amazing yet brutal. But sadly there's just too many flaws with the game for me to justify thats it is worth £23.99.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR; Ninja rabbit game involing beating each other up after just pakouring like an assassin in a sandbox world (For now)
Overgrowth,
A currently in-Alpha Sandbox,Level-editor,Brawler and Parkour game, where the enviroment is your most effective weapon and the factor that usually determines your survival. (And no I don't mean that the Earth just engulfs your enemies when you're about to die)

The fighting is fast paced and based on a sort of skeletal structure, which means if you get hard enough, somethings going to break. IE. Throwing someone over your shoulder and it just so happens they land on their neck and it kills them, or you boot some poor soul hard enough you send him flying into a wall to have his spine broken and then he is paralyzed and no longer a problem.

The parkour, from what I've seen and is very fast paced, wall jumping, wall running, leaping great distances, this allows people to make very interesting and huge maps that require you to be a skilled ninja rabbit (Unlike me because I usually make my rabbits 8 feet tall and obese, so I can use that as an excuse as to why I can't parkour to even save my life) to succeed in such levels.

Speaking of creating very intense parkour levels and such, The Level editor is great for allowing you to, as I stated above to create interesting and unique levels whether it be a large scale battle with swords and spears or an intense ninja parkour challenge, or both, you are able to create it, and if you are too lazy to build an interesting map or the base game materials aren't enough for you, theres a program created for modding the game known as the SUMLauncher(Supported by the Devs themselves) which instantly downloads and places the files in the correct areas so you can use them with no hassle of moving the files yourself, this program has lots of user created mods that range from maps to characters to props.

However the game is still in Alpha and if you're not the person to purhase early and follow a games progress untill its finished then perhaps wait until the game is finished as it is very worth it already in its current state, and I recommend getting it early and watching it grow and develop.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While since there is currently not alot to review about this game, you can already tell about the extremly well executed combat mechanics that this game has a huge potential to become a masterpiece.
This game is a meele orientated combat game, where you can play as overgrown animals such as rabbits or wolves. the true strenght about this game are its very realistic meele mechanics, and the way the weapons/fists impact the body of the target creature. Physics appear to work flawlessly, and wherever you hit your enemy, he will react to it appropriately like a very responsive ragdoll with a complex skeleton. Not only the super realistic and authentic combat and its magnificent physics, combat also feels very visceral and fluid, and the body awareness of the player is extremely well done. looking forward to finally see a multiplayer and a campaing, maybe with a good story to round it up...

i will keep this review up to date as things are changing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best tech demo on Steam, but that's the problem.

The Good
As a tech demo, it is outstanding. There's an excellent sense of movement and weight to your character as they move, which makes the freerunning mechanics of game really shine. The combat is brutal, unforgiving and very fun. It's a simple left-click to attack and right-click to block, but add in the quick movement, sound and fantastic animation the combat is bliss. In it's current state there's also an arena mode that to allow you to only fight. It's very barebones, but it demonstrates the games excellent capabilities. The concept of ninja bunnies and other creatures like cats and dogs is great and I do look forward to how this idea will play out. The game is also easy to mod and has a solid creator tool for making your own environments and arenas. Did I mention the game has the best blood physics of any game I've ever seen?

The Bad
From what I know Overgrowth has been in development for seven years and I've been playing it for two of those years. In all that time the game has changed very little. Since I got it in 2013, there have been a few new, but small features, new models, new items and a bevy of bug fixes. None of these however really changed the games experience or made it feel improved all that much. I understand some games take time to develop, but this is just silly given how much money you have to pay for the game. There's no campaign (yet) and there's very little voice acting aside from the occasional grunt and yell. The game also crashes, a lot. There's also a good deal of bugs, some even gamebreaking.

Summary
It hurts to see such a good idea and base game stagnate. It's a lot of fun, but paying that price for something with such a lack of things to do, I just can't condone buying it right now. I can condone waiting for it to improve, but we've been waiting a very long time already so don't get your hopes up. If you really like freerunning ninja bunnies who beat the living ♥♥♥♥ out of each other and you're willing to pay the price, you'll have plenty of fun for a while. If you're like me, someone who expected more for what they payed, add it to your wishlist and wait until a sale or until the game reaches a more complete state.

6.5/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOvergrowth is ambitious. In fact, I've never seen another openworld game quite like it. In it's present state, this game has tremendous potential and requires community support to see that potential realized. I feel that many Steam users have been spoiled by more polished alpha state games and expect the same from Overgrowth. This title is a reminder of what an EARLY ACCESS game really is. Developers bring their games to Steam in Early Access looking for community support to shape the game into something they want to play. This game is perfect for that concept. At the time of this review (update 206), Wolfire is focusing on the campaign mode for the game. However, there is plenty of room for change while the game remains in alpha. I highly recommend this game to anyone who finds it appealing. Everything this game has to offer is out in the open and plain to see. You are getting an openworld close quarters combat simulator. The physics are impressive, and the character models are a welcome break from the staples in the fantasy genre. If you are expecting a polished, complete game, stop looking at early access titles. Only get this game if you are willing to support Wolfire and see this game reach completion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me say that I go into this quick review with a bit of a bias... This has been my most anticipated game for the last 2 years.

Finally being able to get my hands on a Steam release and even the alpha lives up to everything I had hoped for.

Being a ninja rabbit (or the other animals featured in the game) is such fun. Much joy. Many gameplay. Wow. The parkour elements are incredibly fluid and fun to execute. The climbing, wall running, and jumping all feel so satisfying that you'll find yourself doing it over and over again even without a clear goal to do so.

The combat system is fantastic. Technically very simple - very few buttons are used. The system however is incredibly deep and complex - very hard to master. All the characters, aside from being able to carry out loads of moves, can also pick up weapons to use in combat. Those can also be thrown (Which is a lot of fun)

The one mode which convinced me this game has neverended potential is the versus mode. Although only one map is featured, and the mode is literally Player 1 tries to kill Player 2 while Player 2 tries to do kill Player 1" when me and my sister played it for the first time we spent 40+ minutes on it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[+16] Fighting system. No spam-clicking, just hold down LMB and attacks are automated. What makes this special is that every attack is determined by movement. Go left for a roundhouse kick, straight ahead for a pushing kick, stay still to punch, crouch to trip...
[+8] Attention to detail. There are lots of cool touches in this game. Thrown weapons will stick in wood but not in rock, and whether they stick at all is determined by where it lands. Every move is physics-based - when your rabbit punches, instead of animating a punch and reducing the opponent's health by 10, it properly simulates a rapidly moving fist, calculates pressure, and then applies damage based on relative velocity. All behind the scenes, so what you get is a cool fighting system that's really smooth.
[-4] Infrequent updates. There's a lot already there, but the devs (a team of 3, by the way) release updates preeetty rarely.
[-8] No real structure. A handful of challenges, and arena mode... that's it. This would be a deal-breaker if the blow wasn't lessened by the expansive level editor.
OVERALL SCORE: +12

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never felt the need to post a Steam review before, but here goes. I truly wish I never bought this 'game' almost 4 years ago. I am baffled as to why there are so many positive reviews of it. I feel as though the majority of people here are trying to justify their purchases. I respect all Early Access Games to an extent, but this product has been in Alpha for over 6 years now, and there is absolutely no difference in gameplay since the last time I played it.

The developer has focused all his time improving the physics and game engine for 4 years, which is not acceptable at all. Especially considering the fact that the changes are not noticable at all. There doesn't appear to be any core aim to this product at all, to me it is nothing but a ragdoll rabbit fighting game that gets tiresome after 20 minutes of playing.

I am shocked they are charging £22.99 for this. Before buying this, please have a look at the older Alpha videos on Youtube; for example Alpha 109. (The current being 205...) and judge for yourself wether you do in fact see any changes.


(EDIT: 2016, January 29th) Wow. It has been years since I posted this review. Played it again just now to see that absolutely nothing has changed. I wish Steam refunds existed back then so I could have gotten my money back.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly just to make it clear I enjoy the game without a doubt but my real reason for not recommending it is the time it has taken. I played Lugaru at an early age and in these following years I have been awaiting Overgrowths release for years. It is and definitely will become (if it ever is finished) an amazing game in the years to come. I really enjoy this game but with no story it gets boring very quickly and please read before judging me as I do enjoy this game but many reasons make up why I don't recommend it.
Pros:
•Gameplay is awesome and action packed
•Physics are awesome
•You can play as ninja rabbits, dogs, rats, cats, wolves, hares.
•Graphics are good and blood is quite realistic

Cons:
•Been in development since 2008 (Most new games an indie team makes game in year or less to release into early access, this game has been in early access for 7 years now and the team consists of 4 people)
•Boring with no real story
•Glitchy at times and you can't say 'its understandable' as its in early access FOR 7 YEARS! (I understand most other indie games are released really buggy and some not with such good physics and great graphics as Overgrowth, although I fail to see why it has taken so long and updates consist of minimal changes at times)

Overall it's a good game with a lot of potential but then again this potential has still taken 7+ years to unveil itself and I am not sure at this rate of updates (about once every few months) that it will become great in a short space of time. It could mould into an open world/parkour/survival game where you kill other animals for pleasure or food, build a hut to live in, etc,  etc. The future of this game is in the devs hands and it doesn't seem they know what to do with it. They have had more than enough time to at least make it something better and they have failed to do so. I think they can still improve and make this an amazing game, but for now its not recommended by me.

Note: Its been 8 months now since I wrote this review and still, main thing being added in updates is bug fixes. Take a look for yourself, this was  the most recent update (in a while)

New arena mode
Major optimizations like instancing and z-prepass
Option for simplified shadow rendering to greatly improve performance on slower GPU
Can enable and disable mods from different folders, instead of having to overwrite game data
Post processing including color grading and HDR bloom
Global illumination through tetrahedral light probe mesh
Updated renderer from OpenGL 2.2 to 3.2 core
Script improvements (dictionary support, script fragments, etc)
Fixed arena crash bug (usually when a level ends in which weapons were used)
Command line flags to load specific levels or alter config

New update:
Added 3  New Arenas: Cave Arena, Magma Arena and Waterfall Arena. Story Mode now has levels although as soon as I load them it crashes the game

Do you like animals? Do you like karate? Do you like animals beating the living crap out of each other? Then you will love this game. There are about 7 different races of animals to play as (all mammals) rabbit, rat, cat, wolf, dog, and ROBOBUNNY! Each has its own attributes, rabbits jump high, rats are short- derp, cats... i dont know what cats do yet, wolves are one hit killers, i have no idea what dogs do, and robobunnies cause lag.There is plenty of things to do in this game, will without campaign- sadly, there is still a large sand box allowing you to make custom levels and even your own campaign, dialog, outfits (in a way). While this game advertises parkour, i still have yet to climb to the top of the most simpliest of pillars, but it is an indie game and i soon hope to see some improvements and more content. To top it off, the controls are responsive, good karate moves, fun with sharp things, and great mechanics, but to every good reveiw there is a bad part. This game is more for higher end computers, the game is lacking in content like a campaign, and ironically hitting people causes lag- which is a good thing because its not like the point of the game is to hit anyone right?  Now for the only part you are probably going to read, do i suggest this game? What you see in the video on the store page is pretty much all there is to it, but it is already well polished and even if you arent interested in it now, jump on and when the game hits its full price you might like it, or just buy it to support the devs. Anyways thanks for reading these last few sentences, or really thank for reading this paragraph i forked 10 minutes over to.
What you need devs, is to fix some weps (dog hammer, glaive, ect) and co-op, i have been enjoying the rabbit dropkicking goodness that is this game for almost a year, which means the versus isnt really doing it for me and my cousin. so if you could add co-op challenges, maps, or arenas, i would be most greatful. Also cuddos for you if you actually bothered to read this far into my review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ros:
- The game is the first game (Besides Lugaru, their earlier game) that has had this fantastic and intuitive combat system.
- It is quite unique to find a game where you have the same chances to die as the AI enemy has, and all that keeps you alive is skill. Take for example Call of Duty where you have much more health than the AI opponenets. Of course there is also a need of skill in Call of Duty, all i'm trying to say is that Overgrowth is very unique on those two exact points. And for this point i count it as a pro, but someone else could easily count it as a con, so as i said in the beginning, these are just my opinions.
- I've always loved gladiator games/modes and the arena mode in Overgrowth is a great idea. But as much as this is a pro, it's also a con, becuase i feel that they could have improved the mode so much. For example they could have added the actual possibility to achive something like a new rank, so you could compete global. Take for example the Fifa Ultimate Team mode, they feature divisions, and if you win enough games out of 10, you move up. They could add things like this to make the game mode a game for itself.
- Superpowers without superpowers. I love how you can jump high, long and run on walls, but what i love even more is that everyone else can too. You're not overpowered in any unfair way, it is just plain fun! Just as before this may be a pro for some, and a con for others.
- The realism. The fact that some kicks and punches are more lethal compared to others, and it is a mather of the placement. The fact that if you get kicked into a wall you are most likely to suffer dramatically more damage, and you're most likely dead if it was the second kick or punch. Just as before this may be a pro for some, and a con for others.

Cons:
- Lack of worked through gamemodes. As fun as the game is, no matter how much you like it. Killing the same old rabbit without achieving anything just becomes boring at some stage.
- Multiplayer. I really wish that they at some point will add multiplayer to the game.
- The fact that they haven't made one proper level yet also is a bad disappointing.
- The sounds aren't really that satisfying, you could really wish for some better sound effects when the combat system is so great, but the sound just dosen't match you lethal and awesome kicks.

Finally my score for this game would be 8/10

That was all i could think off first handed. I'm looking forward to you guys opinions :-)

- Jaza777

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initially, Overgrowth seems like it would be a lot of fun to play; parkour, contextual combat and quite a few weapons to fight with. There are plenty of levels that people have created where you're given a huge tower to climb or have to fight enemies, but there are currently no campaign levels created by the developers themselves.

At the moment, Overgrowth is little more than a level editor with decent (but shallow and fairly limited) combat. With the combat being as limited as it is, there doesn't feel like much reason to play the game right now which is made worse by the lack of multiplayer. From the sporadic updates the devs give on their YouTube channel, it seems likely that the game will end up being genuinely good once the game has some focused level design. However, considering it has been in development for six years and has only a small possibility of being in beta by the end of the year, it's not really worth spending £22 on what is (currently) a glorified level editor. Once the developers release the full campaign mode (which is unlikely to happen for a while) I will probably be able to recommend Overgrowth.

Until the game is fully finished, I would recommend holding off on purchasing it and seeing whether you think the full game is worth it.

I was a big fan of Lugaru, like, played hours and hours of it, did every single campaign, official or not, that I could find, installed countless mods...
And then I came across his successor. Had to try it. So, after watching several alpha updates and a few reviews, I decided that that game was even more worth a shot because of the greatly improved graphics and ragdolls.

Alright, it's an alpha, it's in development, there's no campaign yet, there are still a few bugs... But I love it.
Tons of fun, just walking/running/parkouring the maps, fighting countless enemies in the arena, playing like a ninja, using dozen different weapons, installing every single cool mod I can find and creating maps, characters and new things.

Will probably love it even more when it will be finished.

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lugaru, at its time, was a very mechanically sound fighting-game for what  the developers had at the time, and Overgrowth is sure to deliver once it finishes development. For where Overgrowth is at now, it shows great potential of being a great third-person fighting game with anthropomorphic animals, but don't let the latter turn you off. The fighting mechanics are easy to learn, but difficult to master, with precise timing being the key to whether you defeat you opponent or you ♥♥♥♥♥ing pummeled to the ground. The game also shows off its beauty with a very gorgeous engine, with the models of each character being well-detailed and constructed, and the enviorments, although simple, showing off some very interesting architecture. The technology for the damage system is quite nice as well, with it being based off skeletal-like models, and recieving more or less damage in certain areas and how hard the impact is on the models. Weapon combat, just like in hand-to-hand combat, is very difficult to master, since the reaction time needed to block and parry attacks will determine whether you instantly get killed or come out unscathed. With the weapon combat comes the very nice blood decals, with every slice, stab, and thrown weapon leaving a nice, sharp cut or hole of blood on the body, probably the most realistic i've seen thus far in video games, though it only leaves blood marks and doesn't show signs of any physical degradation.

But probably one of the biggest strong points of Overgrowth is its editor, which leaves the user to creating their own maps, missions, and stories to their hearts content. With the devs leaving a fairly abundent assortment of props, enviorments, path-finding and other tools to the user's disposal, it leaves the user with their imagination on what they wish to create, or what they want to test. Though it will take time getting used to a rather bare-bones UI, the capabilities given supplies the user a tool that will keep the game alive from now until hopefully way long after release.

Although Overgrowth is still in development, it shows its technologic capabilities greatly, leaving only a few bugs and still incorporating mechanics like stealth into the mix. Although non-existant, it will be left to the users imagination what the story of Overgrowth will be about, and how our favorite ninja-rabbit Turner is doing after the events of Lugaru.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOvergrowth is a fantastic game that deserves far more attention than it has ultimately received. The fighting mechanics are some of the best I've ever seen and the parkour is great. Overgrowth can be very challenging at times, but after some practice you'll probably be able to get the hang of it. The sandbox mode is fantastic and the level design is remarkable. There are also a ton of great features that I wish other games would implement into their user interface somehow. Plus, the graphics are amazing for an indie game! But so far, there is no actual story mode or any missions. I would recommend buying this game later when there is a campaign or waiting to buy it when it goes on sale. Otherwise, I give this game a 9/10 so far.

Don't let my hours fool you, I've been playing this game for a lot longer than it has been on steam, I made the purchase on steam to support the dev.


The combat is fantastic. I've always enjoyed high speed, agile high octane melee combat like what this game includes.
The thing is, the game (last I knew) only has one developer. On top of that, the asking price of 29.99 is a little too high.

Currently all this game includes is a fun combat game where you can sort of design the levels yourselves and make up your own mock campaign. So please keep this in mind that while you're looking at this game for purchase.  It's incredibly fun, but please be aware of what it includes before you purchase it.


If you guys can, please upvote my review so that others are aware of what the game is before they purchase it. Buyers remorse sucks, and this game deserves to be seen for what it is. A great game, but don't expect a campaign or storyline at this time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to like this game, but judging by the pace the development is going, I think my grandchildren are still never going to see the finished game. Ever since I backed the project (what has been maybe a year or two ago) I've seen NO visible changes in the game. Sure, every couple months there's the occasional bug fix, but these usually deal with some animation issue or a minor tweak to combat that you never noticed anyway. The larger bugs, such as the constant crashes or failing to load, the developers have steered clear of and have not attempted to fix in any way.

However, there is one pro to the game - it has, what I consider, the absolute BEST combat in any game out there. It feels like you're really in the action, allowing you to control exactly how you hit while keeping the game very quick paced (and it manages to do this without the mash X to kill" technique many games use - if you haven't looked up the controls
recommended: I think you'll be pleasantly surprised). As such
hoursPlayed: if you find you enjoy sitting in the arena and fighting a couple rounds every once in a while
voteText: then I would wholeheartedly recommend this game. However
helpfulPercent: you shouldn't expect any more progress to be made on it - not now

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Do not buy this if you aren't too great with 3D game engines or level editors, as this game is yet to have much of a campaign and is extremely limited when it comes to pre built challenges and tasks.*

What is great about Overgrowth is the amazing movement and combat system, both are very fluid, enjoyable and challenging. The overall look of the world and design of characters is both beautiful and unique.

Sadly this game has been in development for several years and will most likely not be completed any time soon.

But if you're like me and enjoying setting up your own missions and levels then you'll have hours of fun. And if you just want to jump in to a campaign filled with diverse enemies and challenges... you may have a few years to wait.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ill start saying this will be a great game. WILL be, but IS NOT. I paid 30 bucks and i havn't been able to entertain myself for more than five minutes in one sitting. Although this game has great physics and is fun as all hell to play with a friend, it only takes you like a fight or two before you're just running around. As this stands, which currently I don't think is fair to price at 30 bucks, I would have to say do not buy this game. Maybe a decade from now when the next update comes out they'll add another map.

Pros:
-Excellent physics fighting and character animations
-Overall concept is solid (but not fully backed with story)
-Controller compatable
-Art and play style is unique enough to label this game as its own genre

Cons: (keep in mind these end up like a rant)
-I've seen one update since I bought it, and that was like over three or four months ago
-On the same note: update history is really really bad. Being both very far apart and little changes made
-I have not found any kind of story mode or arcade mode of any kind to give you a goal.
-The two modes that are most prominant are still really bland. Versus in a giant field with a single rock in the middle, and the arena mode is just a big box you fight in.
-I still have not determined what the point of having different races is in the versus mode if they haven't been given any real balancing to make them unique. Changing from a bunny to rat only really makes you smaller, but you seem to still do the same damage and have the same health.
-Weapon combat still seems really awkward, you either slash the enemy down in one swing, or you just throw your weapon and they cant block it.
-The development of any kind of goal in the game is nowhere to be seen. I've seen dev videos showing new things and mechanics spotlights, but where the hell are the missions and challenges? We can't just fight the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI the entire time, theres nothing else to do. Not even a town to go talk to people in a free roam map or anything, no character names with stories or a world to explore and get sucked into the game with. Just... Pick your little map thing and play it for a minute, then close the game.

I apologize for how long the cons were, but really this is a game that needs some major love. I wish i could recommend it to people, I'd like to see it go somewhere. With the condition its in, that will never be the case. The dev's are just pocketing the profit from whoever falls for the cool trailers of fighting. If you see this for a dollar, buy it! Its worth your dollar, but do not support developers that are this bad to thier game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had this game for a long time now, and I still don't get bored with it. At this point, the game is pretty bare, but the potential is astounding, and the physics engine is phenominal; I don't think I've ever played in a better physics sandbox, actually. Combat is simple, but fast and fun. There's a stealth system, a weapons system, a massive array of easy to use world building tools, diverse character models, and the list goes on.

Even in this early build, the game's combat can stand up to that of any action or figthing game out there. Since the player's power level is the same as each NPC, the game quickly becomes about skill and coordination, and in that aspect the game is very rewarding. You'll never find an opponent that you can't take on, and the only thing limiting your advancement is yourself.

Oh, and the game also has a really fun parkour system. Overall, Overgrowth is ♥♥♥♥ing fun, and is my favorite Early Access game. Totally worth the $30 price tag. I can't wait to see how it turns out.

(08/21/2014)

EDIT: My Steam notes that I only have 2 hours on record for this game. In fact, I've owned the game for longer than it's been on Steam, and have only recently begun launching the game via Steam. Because, you know, manual patching is dumb.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(I ripped this straight from my facebook so)

Look,
I know I'm the indie person and all that. But I'm going to do an honest to goodness sales pitch here. It's for an amazing title that I have been following for a long time. Overgrowth by Wolfire. (http://blog.wolfire.com/2014/01/Overgrowth-a205-video-changelog) blog here.
This is a Third Person fighting game with a key focus on ninja rabbits.
The fighting is very bushido-blade esque. As in, each fight is a challenge. You will feel on the edge of your seat and you never quite know what will happen next. Not to mention, each fight is very free form.
Fighting an enemy with a sword? You can either stab them with it, or while they are charging you, throw the damn sword at them. However, this is where the game gets interesting. Most AI nowadays would just eat the spear and call it good. This AI however, is already sophisticated enough (In alpha mind you) to not only dodge the sword, but catch the sword, in mid throw, and then chase you with it
Each fight is as dynamic as you want it to be. One of my favorites was I was in a free for all. (1v1v1v1) and it was down to me and the last enemy. He had me cornered, so using the games awesome parkour system, I ran up the wall, backflipped over the enemy, gave myself a space advantage, sweep his legs from under him and kicked him in his dumbass rabbit face.
Another thing, as stated in his video in his blog, the dev states 'Its 2014, and I believe that people shouldn't have to restart their game in order to see graphic changes from the settings.' So if you switch your graphical settings, no restart needed. It happens in real time, and get this. Since the pause menu is literally just a popup box over the game, you will get to see the changes happen.
Now, here is where a lot of people would be like ugh no.
It is still an EARLY alpha. Like I'm talking command prompt boots from it. It still is kinda crashy, and its 30.00.
But trust me, this is a great investment. And you get a free game of Receiver from it.
The dev is actively working on it, posting constant updates on his blog with youtube videos describing what changes in every patch.
This is worth the 30.00 investment, trust me.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOvergwoth is an astounding parkour/arena game which ranges from fighting enemys in an arena to being in an immersive sandbox world, where you can leap, jump, pounce, and maneuver your way around the world however you want. Just Like mirrors edge, you are able to run on walls, do wall jumps and many other outstanding moves. You are able to customize the world any way you want by adding objects or even adding enemys. The fast paced fighting in this game forces you to think fast and determine how you will strike your enemy. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys adventurous fast paced action games, and with all the custom maps and updates the community comes up with. You will never get bored of this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game, man.

This game.

Although that should be enough of an argument to go and buy the damn game, you may want reason.
The graphics are very good, in their own special ways. When you are bashing another rabbits head into the floor, the sunset behind you will encourage you to destroy all rabbits.

The combat system is fast. I mean LIGHTNING fast. If you are a quarter of a second too late on a block, you will get hit. The swords are powerful and almost always kill in one hit (as in real life). The combat system is the best I've seen, and since the game is in alpha, it is still getting improved.

And to find more maps, download SUMLauncher. It helps a lot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay guys, I'm updating the review because I looked at it this morning and it didn't seem right.

For a much shortened version, scroll down to Pros and Cons.

Well, here goes.

It's an amazing game, until you realize that the game will never update until the game is out of it's   early access stage, which will take quite a bit of time. Don't get me wrong, this game is great and has Game of The Year potential, but right now there isn't much to do besides fighting at the arena, which after proggesing to harder stages, becomes literally impossible to defeat the giant colored blobs that are 10x faster and stronger than you (this is a reference to one of the major bugs of the game), or you can fight at the maps given, but quickly becomes boring, but yes, you can spawn other rabbits to fight by your side or enemies and make a small battle, but the game is constantly crashing . One interesting feature is the combat engine in Overgrowth, which left me speechless. It's extremely realistic and you must survive a fight by doging, jumping, and countering and blocking your enemies at just the right time.You can also stop the violence and just parkour around a map and run across the walls.

So basically what I'm saying is, save your money for now, because the $29.99 isn't worth it until they add the campaign and more features, not to mention the many bugs in the game.

PROS
-Great fighting engine
-Cool slow-mo feature
-You can do parkour
-You're a rabbit

CONS
-Rarely updates
-Graphics are ehh
-Crappy music
-Little to do

And yes,before you say anything, I am well informed that this game is still in Alpha stages.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One word for this game. Versatile. You can do almost anything in this game, from sandbox to arena to just messin' around ( my favourite). This ability to do almost anything (sorry for repeating) is the reason that i envy Wolfire for creating this masterpiece of indie gaming even when its in this early stage.

Anyway, enough blabbering. If you have some spare bucks that you are willing to spend on a game with high potential and help a developer out, then this is perfect. It's also perfect if you need a game to give you a break from the COD's and Battlefield's of the world (although i still love a bit of Battlefield once in a while). Another thing, this game is perfect as a game to just have a laugh on and not take too serious for anyone who tends to rage quit ( i know i do on certain games).

In conclusion, as a message to the developer, keep up the good work Wolfire and I look forward to what's to come in the future.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhen you buy into overgrowth alpha you are buying into the snippits of what the game can become, your buying into the fantastic lore and world of overgrowth and the unrivled raw talent behind it. One of my faviorite universes in current indie games. The comics and art really drive a story (and i'm not really into comics but these I do read) in what eventually I would imagine a dynamic and interesting world full of unique characters and gameplay. the melee combat engine in my opinion is unrivaled in this games alpha releases and i'm sure WG will use it to its full advantage when creating the game. with the ammount of effort and time dedicated by the developers and artist in one of the original fathers of crowdfunded indie games im sure this isnt going to be a one trick pony game i would imagine the story to be ever continuing or other storys evolving around it or the prospects of some kinda player driven gameplay who knows ? Keep and eye on this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it works it's good, messy fun. It's a very early alpha and the content is minimal but it loads so fast that you can just jump in and out whenever you feel like it. It's also extremely graphic because of how the damage system works. You don't have HP, you have a skeleton that can be broken.
From watching people play you would think that it has a complicated control scheme but it couldn't be simpler. Left click is attack and right click is block. The combat reminds me of Assassin's creed but less one-sided toward the player. The AI stands a chance against you. In fact, You're going to get your ♥♥♥ handed to you more often than not at first.
Great fun. I look forward to watching it grow.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBe aware this is not a definitive review due to Overgrowth still being in alpha and not complete, these are just my thoughts on the game so far and what I have experienced with it. I had never even heard of Overgrowth until it came to steam only recently and it had been in development years before it even came to steam. I quickly became curious and watched videos on it online to see what the fuss was all about. This game has the potential for greatness. Overgrowth is a third person action game that has some of the most impressive physics combat I've seen. For an independently made game It is an absolute blast to get into a brawl with enemies and come out on top. However with the game being in production it isnt really a game... You see, when you log in to the menu it gives you a variety of premade maps to mess about in. There is no single player story to be had and there are some challenge modes that are very lack luster. However once you choose a map there is an ingame editor that lets you spawn objects, enemies and tweak with the games settings sort of like Little Big Planet. This is where things get interesting. You can create different senarios to the existing maps and can even share your creations online with other players and friends. It is a bit of an ordeal to do this as you have to sign up for the developers fourms and other time comsuming methods to get it working properly. However once it is done you never have to do it again and it is painless from there on out to share your work. I have to admit the price tag for an unfinished game is hard to justify, but this is purely a chance for the developers to show people their game and to promote it. I think Overgrowth has some great ideas to become an awesome game and It is worth to give it a shot. Not only will it help an independent game developer but give this game the attention it deserves.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOne of the biggest features in the current state of Overgrowth is being able to utilize its complex combat mechanics in its arena mode. This mode simply pits the player against one to three AI opponents, round after round, with the objective being not to die. Sometimes the round will be a 2v2, sometimes it’ll be a 1v1, and other times it’s a free-for-all. It is a perfect mode to highlight the most interesting thing about Overgrowth, the combat, and a wonderful place to refine the skills needed to comprehend what’s going on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in very early alpha and I will review it again later. This game will soon be the sequel to the game Lugaru, a full campaign you should check out. For the moment, you can only play pre-made levels such as Dropping In, Gladiatior, Two Bunnies Enter, One Bunny Leaves, etc. This game caught my eye, mainly because of the fact that there were bunnies in it, and I love bunnies SOO MUCH! Let's get on with the review.

Story: 0/10
Overgrowth at the moment has no storyline but is bound to have one in the full release... at least some missions in later builds. I will change this section when that happens though.

Graphics: 7/10
This game has beautiful landscape, amazing artstyle, and cool charactor designs. The blood could look a little more realistic, though.

Mechanics: 9/10
The mechanics and programming of the game is great. There are a lot of things to do such as Climbing, Rolling, Aerial Attacks, Sweeps, Dodging, Ninja Crouching, Throwing bunnies over your shoulder, Throwing bunnies over your shoulder and then curb-stomping them (which is SO satisfying), and much, much more.

Controls: 9.5/10
There's really nothing wrong with the controls. 1-9 changes your player model, jump then hold RMB to cling to ledges (sometimes it flings you upwards then you accidently" roll and satisfyingly break your neck)
hoursPlayed: and other basic controls. I would have given it a 10/10

Overall: 8.95/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being a alpha still, Overgrowth has to be polished if it can be called a compete game. But dont let that stop you from getting it.

Overgrowht has great gameplay. The game can be very difficult at times, with smart enemy AI and weapons that would kill you just as fast as in real life. The fighting goes hand in hand with the parcour. Walljumps and ledge climbing can get you almost anywhere, but they can be just as usefull when outnumbered to escape or make counter attack easier to pull off.

Graphic whise the game looks pretty nice, every species has it's own culture and with it weapons, clothing and more. For now the rabbit's appear to be the main focus. However, there are more kinds of characters implemented allready

Concluding, the game in this stage has some very interesting gameplay mechanics but is'nt finished right now.
Overgrowht is a promising game and I can't wait to see the final product.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game, man.

This game.

Although that should be enough of an argument to go and buy the damn game, you may want reason.
The graphics are very good, in their own special ways. When you are bashing another rabbits head into the floor, the sunset behind you will encourage you to destroy all rabbits.

The combat system is fast. I mean LIGHTNING fast. If you are a quarter of a second too late on a block, you will get hit. The swords are powerful and almost always kill in one hit (as in real life). The combat system is the best I've seen, and since the game is in alpha, it is still getting improved.

And to find more maps, download SUMLauncher. It helps a lot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is sooooooooo good.
I know it is only alpha and a lot of games are releaseing too early in development to get enough money to keep funding the games they are making but I would still recommend this. It isn't fully optimised and i will refrain from saying it is okay as it is only an alpha but the rest is good. Controller support that runs smoothly into 2 player co-op whether it is split screen or one camera.

The combat is delicious and really requires thought and precision. You can even slow done time as to think about your moves carefully and to make cool cinematics. You can level edit and even play custom levels (You have to download them of other websites but it should be getting steam workshop soon).

I don't normally give ratings out of 10 but if I had to I would give it a 9/10. This is because it is not perfect and still needs working on but on the whole is very fun to play, may just with a lack of content. :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay guys, I'm updating the review because I looked at it this morning and it didn't seem right.

For a much shortened version, scroll down to Pros and Cons.

Well, here goes.

It's an amazing game, until you realize that the game will never update until the game is out of it's   early access stage, which will take quite a bit of time. Don't get me wrong, this game is great and has Game of The Year potential, but right now there isn't much to do besides fighting at the arena, which after proggesing to harder stages, becomes literally impossible to defeat the giant colored blobs that are 10x faster and stronger than you (this is a reference to one of the major bugs of the game), or you can fight at the maps given, but quickly becomes boring, but yes, you can spawn other rabbits to fight by your side or enemies and make a small battle, but the game is constantly crashing . One interesting feature is the combat engine in Overgrowth, which left me speechless. It's extremely realistic and you must survive a fight by doging, jumping, and countering and blocking your enemies at just the right time.You can also stop the violence and just parkour around a map and run across the walls.

So basically what I'm saying is, save your money for now, because the $29.99 isn't worth it until they add the campaign and more features, not to mention the many bugs in the game.

PROS
-Great fighting engine
-Cool slow-mo feature
-You can do parkour
-You're a rabbit

CONS
-Rarely updates
-Graphics are ehh
-Crappy music
-Little to do

And yes,before you say anything, I am well informed that this game is still in Alpha stages.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy it. Buy it now. There is not that much content, but you be assured it will come over time. This is probably the best Alpha stage game I have EVER played. The combat? 10/10. The action and movement? 11/10. The game feels amazingly fluid and fun, like Assassin's Creed's and Mirrors Edge had a child! The art is stunning - the blood and injuries are genius in design, they look hyper-realistic! The audio is amazing as well, there are over 2500 sound files, which make all the sounds varied and realistic. The physics add a whole new level to the gameplay; you can drop your weapon from a large height and brutally murder someone using only gravity!
The only missing aspect is a full campaign - there is currently only an Arena and some challenge levels, but many more full levels are promised. Everything else is in place, and you can make your own levels with dialogue, stealth elements, characters, enemies, and everything in-between! The AI is also some of the best I have ever seen - it enriches the combat 10 fold! There are a few minor things that could be improved, but so far it has been an amazing experience.
For a game in its alpha stages, made by an indie team of four guys, this is literally a masterpiece.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this game, for people who want a change in games these day's, yes maybe this guy is taking too long for some people. But if you read his Twitter he's starting to pick up the pace and is soon going to hire more people, so far everything he's done in this game is pretty much superior to all these triple AAA games that create a new and super buggy game every year. The Core mechanics of the game are solid and he's obviously worked very hard to bring it from the ground up like this from scratch. I hate the talking down upon this amazing work he's done, I do agree Wolfire needs some new recruits if he wants to progress this game. Although it's taken a long time many mods give you plenty of more hours of this game and I've been designing my own map, character, and story; With the map editor and character action editors...
But seriously, is really being negative about what he's doing the best option? Why not tell him that he's doing great with all these nice things, but these small little changes like ear twitches should not be the best thing to work on at the moment. What I say he  really should begin working on is the story, mechanics, physics, animation, and levels. I believe hiring people to work on the small stuff like minor bug fixes, small improvements, concept ideas, multiplayer, performance, and graphics. While the main developers can work on what's truly important, the story, level design, and gameplay. I believe we should start motivating David, because he is very talented in what he does but he needs support not negativety for making a amazing game from scratch. We just need to talk him into hiring people that he can trust to help him code, having a team of 10 could possibly durastically increase game production. So please hear me out when I say these things and think about it for a second and help us snap David out of the endless minor improvements so we can have a GREAT GAME!!


*EDIT*

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is sooooooooo good.
I know it is only alpha and a lot of games are releaseing too early in development to get enough money to keep funding the games they are making but I would still recommend this. It isn't fully optimised and i will refrain from saying it is okay as it is only an alpha but the rest is good. Controller support that runs smoothly into 2 player co-op whether it is split screen or one camera.

The combat is delicious and really requires thought and precision. You can even slow done time as to think about your moves carefully and to make cool cinematics. You can level edit and even play custom levels (You have to download them of other websites but it should be getting steam workshop soon).

I don't normally give ratings out of 10 but if I had to I would give it a 9/10. This is because it is not perfect and still needs working on but on the whole is very fun to play, may just with a lack of content. :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy it. Buy it now. There is not that much content, but you be assured it will come over time. This is probably the best Alpha stage game I have EVER played. The combat? 10/10. The action and movement? 11/10. The game feels amazingly fluid and fun, like Assassin's Creed's and Mirrors Edge had a child! The art is stunning - the blood and injuries are genius in design, they look hyper-realistic! The audio is amazing as well, there are over 2500 sound files, which make all the sounds varied and realistic. The physics add a whole new level to the gameplay; you can drop your weapon from a large height and brutally murder someone using only gravity!
The only missing aspect is a full campaign - there is currently only an Arena and some challenge levels, but many more full levels are promised. Everything else is in place, and you can make your own levels with dialogue, stealth elements, characters, enemies, and everything in-between! The AI is also some of the best I have ever seen - it enriches the combat 10 fold! There are a few minor things that could be improved, but so far it has been an amazing experience.
For a game in its alpha stages, made by an indie team of four guys, this is literally a masterpiece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game you play as a rabbit named Turner who is the main character now keep in mind you can change your character at anytime by pressing the number keys above the letters.As Turner you run around doing parkour and fighting your enemys like the all mighty wolf or the agile cat (they have the same attributes as turner exept for the fact that the wolf is extremely over powered). The good thing about this game is that its in alpha so there will be amazing things to come.
What i found amazing about this game is that it is based off a skeleton system meaning that there is no health bar just your body so it is like if you jump and land on your neck you die unless you go into editor mode (yes this game has and editor mode) you can change your characters attributes like his strength, attack speed, run speed ect.
Now for the attacks you can do
1. You can punch (no dip).
2. You can kick.
3. You can drop kick (figured to put it below because its basically an instant kill).
4. You can stab or slash.
5. You can choke people from behind.
6. You can throw your weapons.
7. The most interesting thing i think is the counter attack (this feature is what i think is a good feature)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an absolutely incredible ENGINE. Most people will buy Overgrowth expecting to be able to get right into it and play it, This is not true at all. This is just a very user friendly engine that allows new players to: Join, get confused, hit things, get bored, and leave. At this point in the development I feel as though this developer is not actually doing anything with the engine. He makes updates every other month that include changing shadows a bit or tweaking that small bush on the edge of the map that was overlapping with a rock. This game would be better off being handed to a better developer who could actually make a game out of it.

That being said I think it's still a very fun toy that you can play with and get bored of in about 2 hours. I wouldn't say it's worth 29.99$ but to each their own.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note:Like many of the other negative reviews on Steam, I want to preface my review by saying that I loved Lugaru, and think Overgrowth - even as it is now - is fun, and I hope it'll be a finished product one day.

Actualy Review:That being said, the only question Steam reviews should answer is: do you recommend buying the game? The thing is, I really don't.
I bought Overgrowth years ago, and even though a lot of work has been put into it since, it's very much the same game I played back then. It looks better, has more character models, better UI, all that good stuff. BUT it still doesn't have any substance. It's not a sequel to Lugaru, it's a sandbox tech demo, where you can play around with the Overgrowth engine. And to be fair, the Steam store description and Early Access information both make this very clear.

I have no doubt that if Overgrowth ever gets finished it'll be worth the $30€ price tag. But right now, I wouldn't recommend buying it. People interested in Overgrowth for what it is currently will  buy it regardless of my recommendation, but I think people looking for a game, should definitely wait, unless they're willing to think of the purchase as a pre-order with an undefined release date.

A bit of perspective:Things that have happened while Overgrowth has been in development: Barack Obama get's elected president of the United States, Apple debuted the iPad, the first solar-sail tech demonstration is produced, Osama bin Laden is killed, Japan suffers the effects of a massive earthquake and a tsunami, the Deepwater Horizon drilling platform exploded in the Gulf of Mexico causing the worst marine enviromental disaster in US history, 3d printers and scanners enter the consumer market, mouse genome is fully sequenced, world population breaks the 7 billion mark, usb 3.0 is introduced, 22nm chips begin mass production, Curiosity is launched and lands on mars, I got married, got a job, lost the job, moved houses four times and learned to juggle.

Overgrowth is the indie Daikatana. Except unlike Daikatana, Overgrowth when finished will be awesome, and not the most mediocre entry in its genre.
