reviewText:
Early Access Review

firstly, ignore my hours. i exclusively been using the SUM launcher. also be aware that this game is unfinished, poorly opimized, and plagued with slow updates.. (though the developer is starting to get more manpower to speed things up a bit) i have to advise anyone who doesn't know exactly what they are getting to not buy this game until you've researched what the game in its current state has to offer. before you buy this game you have to be satisfied with whats already there.

ive been running this game beautifully on my hp elite 8000 compaq, it has 4 gigs of RAM, a 244 watt PSU, an intel duo processor, and a geforce 730 2g DDR5 card. if you have a better set up than me you'll probably be able to handle the bigger, more detailed maps you can get from the SUM launcher community mods, but please note. experience may vary.

now the game play is where it all comes together, the parkour is fun, combat challenging and brutal, weapon play is excelent and amount of customizability the editor gives you is wonderful. the editor itself is a bit wonky, and using the editor to create levels/scenarios is where you will face 90% of your crashes. its pretty annoying, but i recomend saving the level after every major change, and when your fps starts to drop in editor to save every single change after that. once you save the level it will load automatically when you pick the level you saved it on. (which is nice) it reminds me of gmod, to get the most out of solo play you have to take the time to set everything up, both games (at least for me) tend to crash alot when doing this, but in the end the game play on your custom level is enough to justify it all.

tl;dr 8.2/10 dont buy blindly

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, i have to admit. This game is endlessly addicting. But for those of you who got bored of it quickly obviously haven't tried SUM Launcher (The Workshop for Overgrowth). But there are some insides and outs for this game.

PROS:
1. great graphics and textures
2. rag doll physics (my personal favorite)
3. level editor
4. editing your character

CONS:
1. not having certain skyboxes or textures
2. failing to buffer data
3. crashing randomly

But wait! there's more! ;)
As awesome as this game is, it's been in development for 7 YEARS! AND IT'S STILL IN EARLY ACCESS! There's obviously a problem, if it's Alpha is past 200, even 150!

But hey, at least it's out for us to play. It's a big improvement from Lugaru. Once it's done, we can continue Turner's adventure to stop new danger or whatnot. I recommend this game, it's really fun to play

Well, when i first found this game many years ago i fell in love. A sandbox game with martial arts and parkour. All set in a unique world.

Pros:
The best fighting and parkour engine i've seen in a game.
Unique setting.
Sandbox
Every character react to everything happening to them. Punches and kicks feel like they are hitting with brutal force.

Cons:
Somewhat slow update rate. (It's in alpha, or beta i think)
AI can need a bit of work.
The singleplayer still needs to be done. (For now it's just a sandbox mode, with preset levels)


But still, for an alpha or beta it is an amazing concept witch is not going to be abandoned. The martials arts are amazing, the levels are amazing, the style is amazing. And if it keeps expanding it can turn into one of the best games of 2015. (My personal opinion)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent sandbox, massive potential, Ninja Rabbit Combat.

Edit:

Wow I can't believe that's all I wrote on this game. Probably because I was too busy playing it. I have more hours on this game offline because I use a community mod loader and launcher to play the game. Overgrowth is in development and has been percolating in the minds of the developers since 2005 when they dropped Lugaru, the spiritual predecessor as they put it to Overgrowth.
The reason I love this game is because of it's combat system. The lead developer mentioned once that he took inspiration from Jackie Chan and Bruce Lee movie fight scenes. I like mortal combat street fighter and every other game in that genre in their own rights, but combos for crazy moves put me off. The combat system in this game is based of attacking, blocking, countering, or dodging. The way you are moving around your target determines what kind of attack you will throw. To counter you have to press the block button which is the RMB or right trigger on game pad.

You'll have to just watch the game played and see for yourself if you're interested. What drew me in was the combat and wall jumping! Also user generated content if you're interested in that kinda thing. It won't be as vital to the game when the developers add their mass of content. AND LORE!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just so you know, yes this game has been in production since 2005 when it was named Luguru 2 (which by definition even in Alpha state i believe it surpasses the first Luguru game). Within 2008 it was renamed to Overgrowth, and in 2011 released on steam. Yes....that's a long time to develop a game....but....note this. This IS NOT a AAA title nor is it made by professional developers. Wolfire is comprised of only 4 devs, and that's why updates come slowly and its still in early access. Also They are now moving to a new engine due to the crashes that is being complained about....Now this definately will take a while with only 4 devs. Now lets get back to talking about a triple A game....which is comprised of not just a single team...but multiple teams of Devs up to over hundreds of developers.....How do you think its capable for a CoD game to come out yearly? Plus in games like those they reuse mechanics and code to make  development easier. And NO this game is not abandoned.

Now that we got that out in the open....lets look at some good'Ol PROS and CONS

+Combat is unique and easy to get used to but not easy to win unless you cheat or....like to spam certain moves
+Great ninja feel, and gravity and movement gives the game an old martial arts movie vibe to it.
+Great Collisions
+Local Co-op works well especially with multiple controller support
+Level editing with every prop and tool in the game including materials, Ai, weapons and....other unique stuf
+stealth and quest creator
+Throw weapons at enemies xD
+Multiple races to fight and play against from dog/wolf/rabbit/mouse/cat people
+Endless Arena Mode (unless u die)
+Great visuals good enough to enjoy, and fit the game itself.
+Slow Motion button
+Button that shoots a magical beam and insta kills everything (cheat attack as i said)
+great ragdoll physics

-Crashes (most occurring problem)
-lag at times....depending on the total amount of data within a single area.
-Long development process (Just be patient and enjoy what it gives)
-Players just judge the game without understanding the situation or how development works >,> and ruins it for others
-A lot of wasted reviews that don't provide any supportive information (just me angry right now xD )

I should also point out there, that they plan on taking the campaign/story from Luguru and implementing it within this since......so far it doesn't have any....so that's something to look forward too after the engine transfer (Unreal Engine 4)

They do keep us posted on twitter and other sites with Q/A's so please check that out if your interested. thanks for taking the time reading this and sorry for the grammar xD

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun. A nice combination of Parkour and Melee combat. WITH FURRIES!!! It has been in development since forever (like 2008), but the updates keep coming and are substantial. Also, having anthropomorphs that are realistic instead of Anime-ish is a nice change.

There is a massive amount of community made content, but you need to do sketchy stuff to get to it. Freaking SPOF.

Anyway, the Parkour is a normal 3rd person platformer, only you are a ninja rabbit. Also it doesn't suck. You can do more modren things like wall running and climb up ledges. The melee combat is interesting, as you can murder people (Rabbits, Wolves, Rats, Cats, and Dogs) by using weapons, or you can beat them up. Or you can keep beating them up after they are KO'ed and kill them. Stealth is important too, as you can sneak up on dudes to choke them out, or slit their throats, but lone guards might run away and get help. Or rush you with a sword. Then there is a arena, you can practice you combat skills there.

It doesn't run very well on my PC though, I think I need more CPU power.

8 Turners out of 10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment I can't recommend this game. At least not for Mac. Performance on the Mac is really very very bad, despite having a very fast iMac 27inch with more than capable hardware it seems to often reach a slideshow fps for some reason. It didn't used to be like this and the game itself has it's awesomeness to some extent, but it's currently simply unplayable on Mac.

Now.. it would be unfair to comment just on the Mac version and leave it at that. The current game build itself has a pretty cool melee focused combat (and parkour style movement) going for it that feels both incredibly fluid and very unique. It's graphics and style is also great, but there's still a genuine problem.

The game doesn't feature any actual game content yet. Well, at least not in form of a singleplayer campaign or story mode or even more of a free roaming sandbox world. At the moment it consists of loading what I would call 'test' levels. Now I am sure it serves it's purpose for testing stuff out, but for a player there's very little value to be had here.

The developer does put out regular updates and that's great, but adding new main game content seems to take a very very long time. To most people I would recommend to wait until more of either free roaming mode with stuff to do or indeed a singleplayer campaign is done. From the current game mechanics in place it is clear the developer knows how to make for decent gameplay, so don't mistake this recommendation for stating the game itself will turn out bad. But for now, I'd wait.
(also.. in case anyone knows how to get rid of the slideshow fps performance on Mac, I'd gladly hear about it and update the above..)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't know that it's worth $30; but you can get it off a website that may include a G, a 2, and an A in the title for around $15. I had to remove the link/actual title because Steam isn't particularly fond of them.

It's definitely a lot of fun if you can run it and like the combat, but updates haven't come too often and it's likely you won't see much more progress than what's offered here in the final release. However, that isn't to say it hasn't definitely been updated. It seems they have kicked up their efforts recently, as well, but I can't say much for sure. There's a lot more to the game than there was when it started off, including the fact that it is MUCH easier to run now. If you own the game and didn't like the way it ran before, I heavily recommend revisiting it.

The game doesn't stretch very far past what you can see in the screenshots and trailer, but for a quick rundown, and things you should consider before buying:
- The game features relatively quick, primarily hand-to-hand and melee fighting, with a very intricate movement system. There are many maps dedicated entirely to parkour.
- The modding community is fairly sized, and extremely dedicated. If you own the game or plan on getting it, you should definitely download SUMLauncher for it as well. You can easily install and manage mods, as well as adjust advanced graphics settings, controls, etc. I consider it essential.
- There are no current plans for multiplayer, though there is a decent mod for it currently in development.
- The dev team is pretty small, and probably won't expand. As of the last few months, updates have come a bit more frequent, but just keep in mind that anything could happen to this game.

Dev blog, keep up with the game here.[blog.wolfire.com]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Game is fun, although not done, it has a LOT of potential. The combat is VERY good, so good I think most fighting games should have the style of fighting that this has and, the ai (although buggy) is nowhere near stupid like most AAA games I've played. The worst thing  is THIS GAME IS STILL IN ALPHA AND I BOUGHT THIS GAME ON THE 115th UPDATE!

I'VE LITTERALLY HAVE NOT HAD A STRONG ENOUGH COMPUTER TO RUN THIS GAME AFFECTIVELY FOR MORE THAN 5.4 HOURS!!!!


REALLY!?!?!?!?

I understand that making a game takes time but, jeez....

The game is fun, and keeps you interested, but again it's still in alpha.

All in all I give this game a 7.2 out of 10.
I do recommend this game to people who don't mind games that aren't even close to done, but has GREAT potential. This game (as well as Starbound) got me into the Early Access games. there were two developers for this game, now there's about 23(I think), so yeah. like I mentioned, this game is nowhere near done, but, when it is? It WILL be great.

I salute game devs that work hard on games like this, and listen to the community, and I know that they will go far, but FINISH THIS GAME! PLEASE!!! IT'S BEEN ON ALPHA SINCE I WAS 12! I'M 17 NOW!!!

All in all, good game, Recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm sure my grandkids will love playing the beta while they're in their retirement centers someday. Might even be able to get more than 20 fps on their beefy rigs too...

In all seriousness, if you're reading this. Do Not buy this game. It should not have been put on steam in this early of a state.
It's horribly buggy, most of it's features are broken, it crashes every time you try to change something in the settings, and they still haven't fixed the problem with the maps finding the texture files on a clean install.

I had high hopes when i saw youtube videos of this game, but then i found out it took the recorders at least an hour just to get the damn thing running to film a 5 minute clip.
It's developers like these guys and Sauropod Studio that have made us lose trust in Alpha backing, and rightfully so.

Much like goat simulator the easiest way to review a game like this is by making a list of things i like and dont like about it.

12 (dislike): Many hidden buttons that can cause you to mess up.
13 (dislike): Of the bugs there are, they are very bad and can be triggered moderate ease.
14 (dislike): mods are confusing to install if you dont know what you are doing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OVERGROWTH


Neutral Evil

The game expresses quite a bit of blood for nearly every action, save for stealth grabs, including blood running down character models from points of damage straight to the ground. It even drips off of the characters onto the ground itself. Very well detailed, with a blood color option of variety.

Very Classy

Considering the small amount of dialogue in the alpha, due to the incompleteness of the campaign mode, there is little that could be SAID about the dialogue maturity, over all the game is very mature in the sense that it’s nothing atrocious or rude, but it is very violent. It is, after all, a fighting game. But it composes itself well and nothing about the game seems childish or over the top. Well poised.

I Might Need Rehabilitation

...when this game is released.
The mechanics of the fighting in this game are VERY in depth for the few number of actual button inputs given. Q, Space, Shift, WADS, Right click, Left click. Besides options/load/menu/creation keys, this is all you need and Q is only used for items (only weapons right now?). But the number of actions you can perform is very deep. You can jump, flip, jump off walls, FLIP off walls, roll, duck, low kick, punch, straight kick, roundhouse kick, passive block, active block (just guard), throw, escape throw, hit them while they’re down, FLYING JUMP KICK, attack with weapons, THROW WEAPONS, climb walls, save fall, roll from fall, sneak grab choke hold, move bodies, roll to pick up weapons faster, catch weapons in mid air after they’ve been thrown at you..I may have missed some actions...but these things combined, with so few buttons, creates a VERY intense skill cap. Multiplayer, which has already started implementation in the form of a special 1 screen game mode (with split screen option even), will be very fierce and competitive right out of the gate. The fighting mechanics take about an hour to get used to. The hand to hand mechanics, after 8+ hours of gameplay, I still haven’t mastered. The weapons mechanics are an enigma to me. The AI actually fights intelligently and will give you a consistent challenge. I could sit here and train for hours, which I have...if the game wasn’t crashing every 30 or so minutes.
It IS after all just in alpha, so this is to be expected. Surprisingly few crashes with that in mind. But they will have to be smoothed out before release.



This game is so shiny, I need sunglasses.

I’ve mentioned this multiple times, it’s in alpha, but it LOOKS and FEELS like a full scale production game, but it’s only worked on by 4 people, bug reporters notwithstanding. However if you ever watch a video, you can see a character’s torso move around… you may think “oh that’s cool it bobs and weaves”. What you are actually seeing is a direct reflection (with very little latency) of the WADS keys being pressed. The feet are simply following along with what the body is wanting to do. And while this is not exactly proportional to real physics, it is very good to have in a game where you need to be exactly where you want to be as soon as possible, and that is what determines how close you ACTUALLY are to your opponent/wall/objective.
The ragdolls are absolutely adorable to watch. Dying is actually fun because of that. Hitting someone at just the right time before they kick the bucket can result in them being sent reeling across the fighting area. It’s rather comical, yet heartwarming at the same time. The game is an absolute gem of quality workmanship and the people working on it deserve a very special recognition for that. KUDOS and BRAVO to them. The game FEELS alive, it LOOKS alive, I mentioned the blood in the addiction factor section. It’s such a well made game, even though, ONCE AGAIN, it crashes frequently.

If this game were a human, it would be a woman. That’s how complex it is.

I don’t even need to go into detail about the complexity of the game as it had to be mentioned in the addiction section due to the high skill cap bringing back for more.
There is also a scripting and level editing mode. Scripting is done through .xml files and level editing is done right in the game itself, including placing actors/objects.
However, it’s only downfall in this topic right now would be...you guessed it...it’s lack of content. The game itself is great, but it’s not a game yet, but I can’t wait to see it when it’s done. I will be following this game for the next few years to come and you should too.

Summary

Overgrowth is a fun game. The alpha costs money, but even so, it’s worth it. You will get hours of entertainment out of this game and the single system multiplayer is great in itself.
Buy this game if you love developing your skills, violence and parkour.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLet me start off by saying that this game gets infrequent updates and will probably get a full release after Half Life 3. Now that my only major negative point is out of the way, let me say that this game, in my opinion, has the best combat in any game that I have played so far. Instead of a health system, like most games have, the combat is based on a bone structure system, enemies' bodies will react realistically to being hit, and a single fight with one opponent can take quite a while, which might not be good for everyone, but it's something I really enjoy. You can perform various moves that you can figure out yourself, for example a jump kick, that allows you to bounce off enemies and sometimes land head-first on the ground and snap your neck. There are a few levels already in the game, along with some challenges and an arena, but there is a vast selection of custom maps for you to enjoy, all made with the in-game editor. The parkour, while hard to learn, is VERY satisfying once you are able to even perform some basic actions. This game is definitely not without its problems, but shows a lot of promise, especially considering that it's this fun while it's in alpha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment I can't recommend this game. At least not for Mac. Performance on the Mac is really very very bad, despite having a very fast iMac 27inch with more than capable hardware it seems to often reach a slideshow fps for some reason. It didn't used to be like this and the game itself has it's awesomeness to some extent, but it's currently simply unplayable on Mac.

Now.. it would be unfair to comment just on the Mac version and leave it at that. The current game build itself has a pretty cool melee focused combat (and parkour style movement) going for it that feels both incredibly fluid and very unique. It's graphics and style is also great, but there's still a genuine problem.

The game doesn't feature any actual game content yet. Well, at least not in form of a singleplayer campaign or story mode or even more of a free roaming sandbox world. At the moment it consists of loading what I would call 'test' levels. Now I am sure it serves it's purpose for testing stuff out, but for a player there's very little value to be had here.

The developer does put out regular updates and that's great, but adding new main game content seems to take a very very long time. To most people I would recommend to wait until more of either free roaming mode with stuff to do or indeed a singleplayer campaign is done. From the current game mechanics in place it is clear the developer knows how to make for decent gameplay, so don't mistake this recommendation for stating the game itself will turn out bad. But for now, I'd wait.
(also.. in case anyone knows how to get rid of the slideshow fps performance on Mac, I'd gladly hear about it and update the above..)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't know that it's worth $30; but you can get it off a website that may include a G, a 2, and an A in the title for around $15. I had to remove the link/actual title because Steam isn't particularly fond of them.

It's definitely a lot of fun if you can run it and like the combat, but updates haven't come too often and it's likely you won't see much more progress than what's offered here in the final release. However, that isn't to say it hasn't definitely been updated. It seems they have kicked up their efforts recently, as well, but I can't say much for sure. There's a lot more to the game than there was when it started off, including the fact that it is MUCH easier to run now. If you own the game and didn't like the way it ran before, I heavily recommend revisiting it.

The game doesn't stretch very far past what you can see in the screenshots and trailer, but for a quick rundown, and things you should consider before buying:
- The game features relatively quick, primarily hand-to-hand and melee fighting, with a very intricate movement system. There are many maps dedicated entirely to parkour.
- The modding community is fairly sized, and extremely dedicated. If you own the game or plan on getting it, you should definitely download SUMLauncher for it as well. You can easily install and manage mods, as well as adjust advanced graphics settings, controls, etc. I consider it essential.
- There are no current plans for multiplayer, though there is a decent mod for it currently in development.
- The dev team is pretty small, and probably won't expand. As of the last few months, updates have come a bit more frequent, but just keep in mind that anything could happen to this game.

Dev blog, keep up with the game here.[blog.wolfire.com]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Game is fun, although not done, it has a LOT of potential. The combat is VERY good, so good I think most fighting games should have the style of fighting that this has and, the ai (although buggy) is nowhere near stupid like most AAA games I've played. The worst thing  is THIS GAME IS STILL IN ALPHA AND I BOUGHT THIS GAME ON THE 115th UPDATE!

I'VE LITTERALLY HAVE NOT HAD A STRONG ENOUGH COMPUTER TO RUN THIS GAME AFFECTIVELY FOR MORE THAN 5.4 HOURS!!!!


REALLY!?!?!?!?

I understand that making a game takes time but, jeez....

The game is fun, and keeps you interested, but again it's still in alpha.

All in all I give this game a 7.2 out of 10.
I do recommend this game to people who don't mind games that aren't even close to done, but has GREAT potential. This game (as well as Starbound) got me into the Early Access games. there were two developers for this game, now there's about 23(I think), so yeah. like I mentioned, this game is nowhere near done, but, when it is? It WILL be great.

I salute game devs that work hard on games like this, and listen to the community, and I know that they will go far, but FINISH THIS GAME! PLEASE!!! IT'S BEEN ON ALPHA SINCE I WAS 12! I'M 17 NOW!!!

All in all, good game, Recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is based on the Overgrowth Alpha (3.January 2014):
Right now Overgrowth is already much fun for players trying all of the mechanics. I personally got it because Nerdcubed did a Lets Play on Youtube on it. It looked like much fun playing with the sandbox and the new arena.

Arena: The new arena gameplay is pretty dope. I love the fights without weapons, because you have to fully use all the mechanics in combat that your rabbot has. Also the polearm fights are awesome, I just throw it and then try to retrieve it while not getting killed. One vs One fights are too easy right now. Just jump towards them and kill them with a precise kick.

Sandbox: The sandbox does not have a hughmangous amount of stuff to do, but it is fun and I enjoyed playing it. Play with the mechanics, build your own challenges and fight against an army of rabbits and wolves.

Also it is possible to download custom made maps through the SUMLauncher (retrievable through the secret" Overgrowth Alpha forum at Wolfire Games). Some of them are already great

Early Access Review

With more staff on the Overgrowth team we can expect more updates and quicker, obviously this game isn't dead as it still has been getting updated and it is shown the devs care about it still.

As is right now its a bit pricy but to me it is all perfectly fine, I love the game as is. Maps take some time to load but once they do the game is pretty stable most of the time, for me at least. Gameplay is fun and it's not just rabbits, you got cats, dogs, wolfs, rats, and custom races avaliable through mods. The in-game races are unique and have different mechanics, like wolves insta-murdering everything and the rabbits being faster and more agile.

Don't let the negative reviews fool you, watch some gameplay, get it on a sale, it's honestly fun if you give it a chance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm reviewing this without recommending it. Hopefully by the end of this it'll be somewhat clear why.

This game is really cool. It's a third person outdoor map game with awesome running, jumping, climbing and fighting mechanics. The dude who made the game made the engine himself from scratch and it is slick as HELL. It runs wicked smooth on hardware it doesn't have any right to run so smoothly on and looks great. The animations for everything from crouching to running to fighting to jumping and rolling are also slick as hell. The guy making the engine is incredibly talented and has done some really neat stuff with animations that make the game very immersive. The combat is pretty realistic and enjoyable too. You can get into some very fast, very intense kicking/grappling/swordfighting fights that are very brutal and satisfying.

Now, having said all that, I'm not sure this game is EVER going to be finished. I backed it on kickstarter a few years ago just because I happened to have a bit of cash and thought hey
date: this looks like it deserves support". While the game has certainly had a fair amount of updates

hoursPlayed: in other words: all tech. I'm worried this game is going to get stuck in a permanent "tinker" phase and nothing concrete that can be called an actual game will ever come out of the process

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is game is ok in the fighting combat engine that Wolfire did, and I applaud that. But thats about the only thing i applaud in this game. Its buggy, its been an alpha for years. The bundle with Recievers ok, but Reciever doesnt even have a story and its just an excuse to buy this game so you think your getting a deal. When you Alt+Tab out of the game, it totally bugs out. For some reason, the level editor and the level are one thing. Thats not very good. Also if you spawn in an enemy, they'll only fight when you are in the level editor mode, they won't fight when they are in the game. The arena mode can be buggy aswell. Its a cool aspect and all, but if you use the lightning bolt thing ability to kill everyone nothing can be decided because the game can't figure out that everyone died due to you. Also, I grabbed this on steam a few months back, and there hasnt been an update since before I even owned the game. The game was appeasing before as a cool little alpha that should be more reasonably priced or just kinda free. This game is a bad deal for an alpha, nothing that this game is nowhere near complete. The developers need to learn better management and to maybe just release a quick update that may fix some issues with the game and make the level editor mode in a different function of the game. This game has alot of potential, but the game developers aren't caring enough to take it. If you asked me, I would just buy some other game that has a physics based engine like this, which are not scarce on the internet if you just search a bit. Good luck to the developers and I hope you figure out something new for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many of the popular comments are negative on Overgrowth's slow development, but keep in mind they hired more devs recently and updates went from several month gaps to 1-2 weeks each. That's good for Overgrowth, which from the start was built from scratch, on their own engine, that simulates realistic physics, forces, impacts and flowing blood, all in real-time. It runs smoother than butter for me.

What it is currently is really a sandbox. There's a big selection of pre-made levels, mostly Arenas and landscapes, and you can spawn in many items (trees, buildings, NPCs, weaponry). There's a lot of potential to make your own stuff too, since you can resize and transform assets as you please, as well as plot paths for NPCs to move on. Personally I'm not too interested in all of that but it leaves huge room for mods, which you can download from the SUMLauncher on the Wolfire site.

But enough of brushing over the technical details, the gameplay is key. Combat is phenomenal in every way. You can throw your adversaries over your head, kick them to death, roundhouse kick their faces, disarm them, whatever you please - all of it can be done by the left and right mouse button. Incredibly easy to learn, incredibly hard to master. The game's got fluid animations and motion too, and it's very easy to do parkour and blend that into fighting. Wallrun, jump off and slam dunk a bunny. This game's got it all.

I personally love this game, though I understand it's not for everyone. Something something furry heaven, blah blah development hell etc. For what's in the game now I think it's well worth your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As previous reviewrs have mentioned, development is slow, but considering it's a one (or two/three) man team working with an engine they created - a good looking and ambitous one for such a small team - of course it takes time to make changes to such an engine.
If you've ever played Lugaru and wish to support their Dev(s) in their goal to create a sequel and help them along the way with feedback (Wich is what Early Access is for, not buying, complaining about an unfinished game and getting a refund as you downvote it; Which ironically makes it harder to develop as funding is pulled) then go ahead and spend the money if you can spare it.


Also, you can play Local Co-Op and kill your friends. Just don't downvote becuase you don't know where the controller goes into your computer.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOvergrowth er et sindsygt godt spil. Jeg har aldrig nogensinde spillet med bedre 3rd person engine og det er særriøst detaljeret med den måde som man kan slås med andre deltagere. Mekanikken i spillet giver spilleren lov til selv at have en kampstil. Er også stor fan af den måde pillet ser ud på. Istedet for elvere eller orker har man kaniner og ulve der render rundt med kamoflage dragter, svær og spyd, hvilket i mine øjne for alting til at se meget mere dystert og rådt ud end rigtig mange andre spil. Overgrowth kan helt sikkert anbefales hvis man godt kunne tænke sig noget mere udfordrende og fremmed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overgrowth has potential, but the developers seem to have no intention of actually finishing it.  Which is a shame, since they're doing a lot of really cool stuff.  You can't really call it vaporware, since they actually do update on a regular basis, but it's more of an ongoing experiment than an actual legitimate game development effort.

I'd like to see Wolfire get serious about this project.  Until then, I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is a lot to say about this game, mostly postive, but I will try and cut it down to basics. I cant really do an average rate of each element yet because this game is so under-developed. It is very much alpha, and will probably be some time before we see a full-release. That alone can be a negative for most. Im going to tell you why its not.

1. The developers are doing something amazing here. This is already one of the most complex combat games I have every seen. Its one of the few games out there that repects physically to the full extent durring combat.

2. It has a continuely growing gameplay and updates are added frequently. They are not only building a storyline game, but a mod friendly, developer game. Right now, you can change everything. They give you as much ability as them, and that is currently what the game is.

3. The vast ability oft his game is more than a few blank maps, 1 model enemy, a few weapons, and thats it. There is some of the most creative maps I have seen in a combat game in awhile. The time era here is difficult to pin, (Because all characters are animal :P) but they only have swords, axes, spears, hammers, etc. that makes the games combat a little more interesting, and forces it to be more detailed.

4. Despite the fact that you play as 7 foot tall rabbits, dogs, cats, rats, etc, this game is very realalistic. You can literally kill yourself by jumping of a high structure and snapping your neck. The sword fighting is also very detailed. Ending a 3 minute battle with no hits with a slow motion throat slit of your enemy is satisfying to say the least.

If you dont like waiting for a game to have its release, and hate waiting on developers, maybe this game isnt for you. But its a shame is you dont, because you have no idea what your missing out on. When this game has its full release and has an amazing story, the best combat ever, beautiful graphics, and is rated extremely highly. Go ahead an buy it then. Im just trying to say you're gonna miss out on some very intriguing gameplay pre-release, and getting to keep updating with developers to witnesss one of the best games ever be made. FROM SCRATCH REMEMBER.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBefore i start this massive paragraph *cough cough* (story), Yes, I do like this game. As a matter of fact, i love this game and it's built very well. Though there are a few Minor/Major issues that make this review slightly negative. When i start the game, i am givin a code, just like everyone else, but when i go to activate that code, it says its invalid. Oddly enough, i can still launch the game like normal and play all the maps. But when i launch the map, 75% of the time, it crashes, now this isnt my hardware, it just that when i launch the game, it just exits out. Not sure why, but, to the next topic. The physics and combat in this game are amazing, and the graphics are great, overall, the game is built very well (as long as it's running properly). But when i am in the game, most of the functions i can use don't even work, for example: I cannot pick up weapons, I cant change my settings, Keybindings, or resolution (I found a different way). Basically, its impossible for me to actually fight using weapons. Though fighting with fists is quit fun, not with a wolf though. So, this is my overall Rating for the game (FOR ME, NOT FOR PEOPLE WHO'S GAME IS WORKING PROPERLY): 7.8, Because the issuses bring down some points, but i can tell the developers worked very hard on this game and i am very appriciative about their work, Great job! Honestly the problems i have dont really effect gameplay at all, i just ignore them. One last thing, if you want to play this game at max settings, with high resolution, i suggest getting a better graphics card, this game is absolutely beautiful! Love it!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLet me talk about Overgrowth,Overgrowth I think has the most diverse and unique combat system. The combat is fluent but still needs work. Some of the weapons are op and need some nerfing The game itself is still buggy and crashes from time to time,But its still in alpha so it will pass. The parkour is decent and even But still needs other things added into it like when running you could just hoop over an object instead of just jumping over it. Npcs are mysterous you never know what it will throw at you. The game is not finished yet and things like *multiplayer haven't been added and there is no workshop other then the sum launcher. but again a game like this needs to take time to build. For now I give it a 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game. Its fast, skillful, satisfying, challenging, gorgeous, well animated, smooth, gruesome, runs very nicely on even some lower-middle end computers, highly customizable in that the editor is outstanding and intuitive which allows for a large community to express itself, and it is extremely detailed and accurate in both it's combat and animation.

It would be very cool to see this have a vast open world compaign with a script written with help from the community. As of now it is only closed levels but they are quite large, customizable and beautiful.

With all this being said, there is still one major issue I have with this game: So you've got a game, a very well sculpted game, that has a vast amount of code and attention to detail, but its almost as if you've built a mansion on wobbily stilts. Its like a one legged chair, the leg is rounded on the bottom yet you have a masterpiece of a throne on top. The game crashes a lot. It needs a stronger foundation in order to keep itself upright, if you want to think of it that way. Thankfully the crashes usually come during intense combat and not level editing from what I've seen, it could be different for others

So would I recommend this game? Whole-heartedly, yes. There are plenty of fixes for the crashes and you can send the crash files to the developer. The game has been in development for a long time and has only gotten more and more popular.

As a side note to the developer, I and probably a large portion of the community, wouldn't mind a period of time (however long it takes) where the only updates were crash fixes and foundation builds. The game is very much so a sandbox and doesn't need menu updates or any of that for a bit in my opinion. I would just like to see a stronger base. Thank you.

And to whoever is reading this, I would pick this game up ASAP or at least keep it in the top 3 of your wishlist. Its a great game and I don't think I will ever get sick of it (that means a lot coming from the person who can't stay on other games for more than 5 minutes).
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I watched this game from mid-2013 to the end of 2013... I have owned this since slightly before the start of 2014 and how played it in bouts here and there whilst reguarlly watching the game progress.

In Short: An arguably revolutionary combat system... simply seek other reviews or watch the (engine) demonstration videos for this game (the dev(s) is quite involved with PR and does these videos quite well)... read the Early Access readout on the main page if you have not already.


In Depth:

I highly recommend this unique game due to its' movement/combat systems... especially if you like playing local co-op matches.

I have not used the editors/modding capabilities of the game (https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=Vb9NK2t2JuQ&x-yt-cl=84359240&x-yt-ts=1421782837)... but have played around with the controls, which are not listed in the game: http://wiki.wolfire.com/index.php/Control_Reference and to get an idea of where the game is going (to see if you want to drop 25-30 bucks on the game (the cheapest I've ever seen it is when it was reg: $25 sale: $20)), you may wish to buy Lugaru HD (for $2.50 when it is on sale) as well as read over reviews for it: http://store.steampowered.com/app/25010/) if you like it.... the combat system in it is similar, antiquated, but still worthwhile... Overgrowth puts the onus on the player more-so than Lugaru did for attacking when jumping off the wall.

You can catch weapons, you can block attacks, you can counter attacks, you can select how you attack via a mouse click, LMB+D, LMB+A... well just reference the aforementioned Overgrowth Control Wiki[wiki.wolfire.com] in the Attack and Defense" section if you desire to understand how the combat works then watch some gameplay videos.

One can use a controller with the game... but only in combat currently... mouse and keyboard feels fluid though (as I am that type of player)... but the controller controls were suprisingly intuitive/easy to use last I tried.

PvP (1v1... versus) Local Split Screen - Convert to this game already you 2D versus brawlers... or don't
date: idc.\n\nThis video might be meaningful to you all: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZoWa3Z_w99s"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a fantastic game with numerous qualities to becoming a hit. It may be in development now but Wolfire is doing a good job on updating and fixing many of the problems. The only problem that I have faced with this game is the lag and extreme drops in the FPS when on a large level with many objects. It is recommended to have a computer that can handle the graphics and speed of the game. I recommend getting it due to the free Reciever game that is attached before it is officially released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has been in alpha for what was it . . . like 7 years or so? Now, most average Joe's would find that a bad sign and just give up, but i find it a good sign. This may not look like an Indie game but it is (yeah, big wow to the average Joe's who don't check the tags) and a game like this takes time . . . especially as an indie game. There is no multiplayer yet and i have multiple missing textures for the sky . . . which should be fixed, lots of bad sign's but when this game is finished it will have multiplayer, and hopefully no missing textures. the combat is great and the parkour is fun, making your own levels is extra fun. Just give the game a chance, and if you don't like it well now Steam has a refund system so there you go . . . just try it.

EDIT: I forgot to mention that the game does crash once in a while but what can you expect from an alpha? I doubt that will be the case in the finished product. Also forgot to mention that this game does have local multiplayer and controller support.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is my definition of sad.

The combat system is so beautiful and satisfying. The slow motion fighting is the best and I can spend so much time running around and jumping in slow motion.

But

This game lacks content
No levels to beat
Just an arena mode and a hard to use sandbox which would take 5 hours to create your own level.

This game is not going to be finished
There have been no updates in almost 6 months.

I would have refunded this game if steam refunding hadn't of come out earlier.

So do not bother with this game as it will lack playability and it is a waste of money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overgrowth is a well spoken about game on youtube, but still dosen't get the publicity it needs to have. Created by Wolfire Games overgrowth is more of a spiritual successor to the game Lugaru that a sequel at the moment. There is no true point to the game yet, it is a free roam thing with an IN DEPTH level editor with plenty of ways to make machinima and custom armoer for your character. In the game you play as a delightfully awesome cast of human? like? animals that include so far as bunny(with different types of bunnies),cat,wolf,dog, and a robot bunny? Each character has there own perks from running faster, jumping higher, or when it comes to the wolf ANIALATING ALL ENEMIES VERY QUICKLY. As well as amazing intuitive smooth parkour which i am in love with, it has what i would only describe as the best combat in all of video games. A system were rather than puncg with individual clicks, you enter a battle mode by holding the mouse button allowing you to focus entirely on what forms of attack you will perform usiing the directionals,crouch(shift),and jumping(space to perform the coolest manuver in all of video games!). The blocking system is fast you must block at the right time when the blow would have hit you which isnt easy even when the games in slow motion, oh yeah by the way tab makes the game slow mo and double tapping it freezes the game... HOW ARE U NOT BUYING THIS. As of now there is no story but the level editor and arena mode(truly test your combat skills) is enough to keep me entranced hours on end. Best part about it with steams auto update system you can be sure you are getting the most of the experience. The company that makes it, Wolfire, seem like cool guys(or guy?) on there website and forum you can see the latest news on updates and how to play the game not to mention there youtube channel Wolfire Games. I can see they have alot of hope in this game and truly want it to go places i mean its been in work for a while. With mods and hopefully in the future Steam Workshop support i cant imagine putting this game down.

Rating- Buy it if u value your life

Gang beasts is similiar and just recently got updated for the new unity engine. i might get that soon, but i want to wait until it comes out of early access, otherwise i might have two unfinished physics based combat games in my library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely worth the money. This game takes a two/three (depending on how you look at it) combat system to a whole new level. With the great physics and the fluid combat this game has A LOT of potential.

My only wish is that they will add in a Multiplayer over the internet. If they can do that the game would get a 9.5/10 from me. If not it's still like an 8/10 for a game in alpha.

Even if no MP is added, the single player is fun, and sounds fun. Tons of challenges and hopefully more campaign missions soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though this is entirely not complete - it's still an awesome concept and fun, even without there being a point yet.  The physics are pretty cool and the rag-dolling of the avatars is very amusing.  It controls a little like a fighting game, Assassin's Creed and maybe one other action title, so it's actually not hard to pick up and go.

Right now, the attacks are a little unrealistic, I should not be able to punch someone in the chest and knock them out instantly - I mean... they're ninjas too, you would think they could take a few more than 3 hits...harharhar.  I never played Laguru, so I don't know much about the story-line for the character, but with the way the world looks and what I've read about the overall story, this game is going to just plain kick ♥♥♥ when it's complete.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOvergrowth is a unique 3rd person fighting game. You can parkour off walls and ledges; seeing as you play as a rabbit, you can jump really high and far. Even though it's in alpha, it plays beautifully. So far, there is no mulitplayer. But Wolfire has already promised the creation of multiplayer and a full campaign. It's fun to play around with the ragdoll and the slowmotion effects. I have really high expectations for this game, and even though its cost is higher then you might want to pay, I bought it on a whim, and ended up getting lucky. If it's fun as it is now, I can't wait to see what Wolfire has in store for us. And now it comes with Receiver, which i suggest you also look into.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overgrowth is a well spoken about game on youtube, but still dosen't get the publicity it needs to have. Created by Wolfire Games overgrowth is more of a spiritual successor to the game Lugaru that a sequel at the moment. There is no true point to the game yet, it is a free roam thing with an IN DEPTH level editor with plenty of ways to make machinima and custom armoer for your character. In the game you play as a delightfully awesome cast of human? like? animals that include so far as bunny(with different types of bunnies),cat,wolf,dog, and a robot bunny? Each character has there own perks from running faster, jumping higher, or when it comes to the wolf ANIALATING ALL ENEMIES VERY QUICKLY. As well as amazing intuitive smooth parkour which i am in love with, it has what i would only describe as the best combat in all of video games. A system were rather than puncg with individual clicks, you enter a battle mode by holding the mouse button allowing you to focus entirely on what forms of attack you will perform usiing the directionals,crouch(shift),and jumping(space to perform the coolest manuver in all of video games!). The blocking system is fast you must block at the right time when the blow would have hit you which isnt easy even when the games in slow motion, oh yeah by the way tab makes the game slow mo and double tapping it freezes the game... HOW ARE U NOT BUYING THIS. As of now there is no story but the level editor and arena mode(truly test your combat skills) is enough to keep me entranced hours on end. Best part about it with steams auto update system you can be sure you are getting the most of the experience. The company that makes it, Wolfire, seem like cool guys(or guy?) on there website and forum you can see the latest news on updates and how to play the game not to mention there youtube channel Wolfire Games. I can see they have alot of hope in this game and truly want it to go places i mean its been in work for a while. With mods and hopefully in the future Steam Workshop support i cant imagine putting this game down.

Rating- Buy it if u value your life

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely worth the money. This game takes a two/three (depending on how you look at it) combat system to a whole new level. With the great physics and the fluid combat this game has A LOT of potential.

My only wish is that they will add in a Multiplayer over the internet. If they can do that the game would get a 9.5/10 from me. If not it's still like an 8/10 for a game in alpha.

Even if no MP is added, the single player is fun, and sounds fun. Tons of challenges and hopefully more campaign missions soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'd really love to recommend this game, but I just can't.

Don't let my opinion sway you, it is a great concept, but it is incomplete, and chances are if it ever leaves alpha, it will likely be in a year or two. This game is fun for a while, but then it gets boring, even when you have someone to play with- but even multiplayer takes some setting up. I find myself not playing for longer than half an hour to an hour, before eventually getting bored.

The physics and combat are great, don't get me wrong. It can be fun running around for a while and doing some parkour, but it is still limited. Very limited.

I understand it is still in Alpha, but it's just like Day-Z Standalone- early access, £20 and feels almost abandoned. The only difference is that Overgrowth has been in Alpha for 7 years. Yes, SEVEN years. I am unhappy about this and I feel that I should be waiting for an announcement for the project being cancelled than a big update coming. The updates recently are small and unimpressive. 3 new arenas in arena mode as well as some bug fixing was the most recent as of writing. They don't even feel like they belong in the game- they are more like mods, and they can easily be replicated in the level editor.

TL;DR:

A great concept, but it feels like it has been abandoned, updates unimpressive and small, Alpha for 7 years.

It is a good concept, but I don't see it coming out of Alpha within a year or two, and for that reason, I am giving it
4/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYeah, yeah, yeah, David's taking a while. Whatever. This game is fantastic and will continue to be that way for however long it's still in development, and much, much later after that. I cannot stress enough that you are a F*CKING RABBIT KICKING THE SH*T OUT OF OTHER RABBITS AND SOMETIMES CATS, RATS, AND WOLVES. I can't stress it enough. The platforming is smooth and connected, the weapons are brutal, and the level editor is very efficient. Oh, and those glitches in Skate 3 that send you to the floor crying of laughter? They're all here as well.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI recommend this game because it is stupid fun even in an alpha stage. I have clocked countless hours and I say that as I have been accessing this game via the SUM launcher and it doesn't count hours. I highly recommend the SUM launcher as well, but it requires you purchase the game in early access. I digress, the parkour/free running is as it should be, not too easy and not too hard, but it has challenge. Unlike the Assassins creed games where it is run at a wall and hope for the best. What makes it better is when you pull of an awesome stunt, look back and feel awesome. Combat is superb, It feels real. You can dodge and counter in many different ways. Like ducking under a kick and sweeping, Sparta kick them when they go to sweep you, roll and hit them from behind or simply parry and judo throw them over your shoulder. The weapons aren't hit

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updates very slowly. Fun brawler. Credit to the Dev for communicating the updates so well. Lots of love and detail put into it. Do not buy unless you want to support it. Buy Lugaru.

Mostly reviewing because I belive the game deserves a positive review. All the negativity kinda sucks. Yes the game updates very slowly, but it's been consistenly updated. And yeah, there used to be a lot less content.

Also a lot of the little details you just kinda miss unless you know about them. Such as the blood, various injury poses, critical damage spots, the ragdoll animations.

It's fun, but ultimately empty right now. Honestly if it takes after Lugaru, the gameplay that there is now, is all there will be. Some platforming, and some satisfying combat.

6/10 for just right now, 7/10 if you like the type of game, 8/10 if you can appreciate the little details. Overall, above average to good. For me, I like it, it's quite good.

But as I say with early access games, buy it ONLY if you're okay with the content in the game right now, and if you're okay with the Dev being a dumbass and potentially releasing a string of bad updates and ignoring the community (seems unlikely here, but still, beware).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updates very slowly. Fun brawler. Credit to the Dev for communicating the updates so well. Lots of love and detail put into it. Do not buy unless you want to support it. Buy Lugaru.

Mostly reviewing because I belive the game deserves a positive review. All the negativity kinda sucks. Yes the game updates very slowly, but it's been consistenly updated. And yeah, there used to be a lot less content.

Also a lot of the little details you just kinda miss unless you know about them. Such as the blood, various injury poses, critical damage spots, the ragdoll animations.

It's fun, but ultimately empty right now. Honestly if it takes after Lugaru, the gameplay that there is now, is all there will be. Some platforming, and some satisfying combat.

6/10 for just right now, 7/10 if you like the type of game, 8/10 if you can appreciate the little details. Overall, above average to good. For me, I like it, it's quite good.

But as I say with early access games, buy it ONLY if you're okay with the content in the game right now, and if you're okay with the Dev being a dumbass and potentially releasing a string of bad updates and ignoring the community (seems unlikely here, but still, beware).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are happy with a pretty buggy and unintuitive sandbox to play in and a repetitive Arena mode. then I suppose this game is worth its pretty high asking price. I however, cannot recommend this game at all in it's current state. The slow process of updates does not really factor into that. There is just not enough game here. Even if it was sale price it does not change  my opinion.

When I bought it, I had hoped for a much quicker turnaround. As it stands, I feel like I have made a 30 buck bet that may pay off sometime in the future. There really has not been a fraction of the progress I had hoped for. And while I kind of appreciate the sandbox editor. I would have hoped that the devs would themselves add more content to the game which still feels like a bare tech demo. Hopefully the finished game will eventually live up to it's unique design and beautiful enviroments. But I have to strongly suggest against purchasing this game right now. If the finished game ends up being amazing then I will gladly amend my review. But as it stands. Keep away until the devs prove out and the game gets at least a campaign mode. Most early access games have the foundations of what the full game will play like. This game throws you a shovel and tells you to get digging.

Early Access Review

I had some fun with this game, on the Stucco Arena level. Granted, it was definitely not worth THIRTY dollars. Ten, at the most. That being said, I HAD fun. That is, when the game wasnt crashing every five minutes, until now the game says its missing files from the only level I enjoyed. Stucco Arena randomly decided to lose all its files for seemingly no reason. Uninstalling and reinstalling, verifying files, and restarting steam all did nothing to help. So congrats, devs. Your unupdated game has claimed another victim. Have fun with my thirty wasted dollars, I guess.
/endrant

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing this game on and off for the past 4 months. It has consistently been a lot of fun, and i'm glad they brought it too Steam so it can reach a wider audience.

TL;DR - Fun, very fluid and brutal 3rd person fighting game with rabbits and wolves, is definetely an alpha so expect bugs and a pretty good PC too run it.

This game at this current stage is basically an arena brawler with rabbits and wolves that are somewhat humanoid"
date: there are a number of different preset scenarios with slightly different objectives. For example
recommended: reach the coloured block without being killed
hoursPlayed: which is quite difficult when there are rabbit guards with broadswords and spears!  There is also a proper arena mode where you are in an actual arena and will fight waves of different rabbits
voteText: this is random and will spawn you with either a friendly NPC or on your own and is a lot of fun.\n\nThe fighting mechanic is pretty unique and reminds of me of kung fu movies
helpfulPercent: it consists of left clicking to attack and right clicking to block and shift to duck and roll
votesHelpful: but it is very challenging at times and looks AMAZING when you finally master it. It also shows blood stains on the characters and on the walls when you get hit against them
votesTotal: and sound effects are pretty good as the actual hits that you manage to connect sound very satisfying and brutal.\n\nYes the game WILL CRASH and yes it is a bit BUGGY
votesFunny: but overall the fighting mechanics are beautiful in action and it feels so satisfying roundhouse kicking a rabbit into a brick wall. The game also needs pretty much a dedicated gaming PC to run well
commentsCount: and i find particularly the areas with multiple guards wielding weapons to take a slight hit in frame drop but otherwise it's great and will only continue to improve as more and more content is implemented."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This games is buggy, EXTREMELY BORING, combat isn't very satisfying, platforming is too simple, the game has been in development since 2008, and now its 2015 and there's still really isn't really anything new at all. The game crashes very frequently, and the load times are worse than sonic 06' at times. I'm not trying to hate on the game, because it does have some redeeming qualities, but considering how long this fricken things been in development, and because people haven't really played since the last time they opened it up, got frustrated by its primary problems and only played it for about 20 minuets and then got bored with it, I don't think the game has much of a future. Even if they add a good story mode, few people are going to go back because a majority of its problems probably wont be addressed. And I am using a pretty modern laptop to run this, and I have RARELY had any technical problems with any other games. Except for this one. Of the 100% amount of fun you can have with an indie game, or just games in general, this game falls between the 15% and 35% range. (at least for me) And you know that this game isn't very good when all this is coming from a guy who absoloutley LOVES open world sandbox games. (like Garry's mod, minecraft, goat simulator, Gta, saints row, etc)

Verdict: Definitely not recommended

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overgrowth is a third-person action-adventure game, and acts as a successor to the game Lugaru, developed by Wolfire Games. It continues the story of an anthropomorphic rabbit, named Turner, who seeks to live with a new purpose, after suffering through many events of loss and betrayal. As of 2008, the game is still in development, with frequent updates made to it.

GameplayOvergrowth is similar to its predecessor in terms of the mechanics of it, with some major tweaks made to it, like detailed environments, improvements made to the context-sensitive combat system, smoother and more fluid animations, and so on. The player can make use of different weapons to neutralize his or her opponents, such as knives, broadswords, and spears. The game is still in Alpha phase, so one can only play the game in its Sandbox-like mode, free to use different character models, and try out different things like arena fighting, or environmental exploration.

VisualsThe improved visuals are a huge stepping stone to making the game much more enticing to its users. Comparatively, Overgrowth produces a much fresher take on the appearance of the characters and the environment to those who are familiar with Lugaru. For an independent developer, this game must be applauded for its overall artistic design.

ControlsThe traditional use of K&M is encouraged here, as the response time is quicker and invigorating. The combat system also works remarkably well with them. A gamepad can also be used, but I would like to recommend the K&M instead.

StoryThe game is still in Alpha Testing, so there is no story mode. The developer instead continues to release periodic Alpha updates, citing new changes and modifications made to the game and its coding. But, so far, what we know is that the game will take place in a pre-industrial era where the anthropomorphic community now exists without a leader, putting their world in a state of anarchy.

ConclusionFor an independent developer like Wolfire Games, they have to be applauded for their hard work they have put into this game, in order to fulfill what a player really needs in a fighter game such as this. I own a Non-Steam version of it, and I've stacked up atleast 30+ Hours in it, because I found it extremely fun to mess around with it, as a way to pass time. But, I will admit that it's been too damn long since the game was in Early Access. It would be best if one gets it when it's on sale, but do get it if you're into fighter games.

ADVICE: I will say that the game is still on Early Access, which means the full version has not released yet. So far, I have not encountered any bugs, except for framerate issues, and a few weird glitches. Buy the game only if you want to support the developers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overgrowth is a 3D Platformer that integrates minor parkour elements like wallruns and flips.  It also features a combat system that is fully dynamic to the player's surroundings.  I recommend Overgrowth of it's level and character design and innovative combat and physics.

However, this game is still early alpha.  Do not expect a polished, rounded game.  It might seem so at the $30 price tag, but really it's just a sandbox at the moment.  A really fun, bloody sandbox.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDon't waste your money. Now don't get me wrong, this game has a good fighting system, graphics, and movement. reviewText:
Early Access Review

this is a really fun game, to be in only alpha! it's fun, creative, but a little frustrating the first times you play it.

when you've watched someone on youtube play it (*caugh* markiplier *caugh*) you see all the cool stuff that happens when you click certain buttons. the only problem is, not all buttons are displayed in the options menu (at least on my pc) and you just have to click random buttons till you get the right one, which can be frustrating of you overlook one, and you have to go back, wondering OMG I did it! .... wait
date: which button did i click?"\n\nthe other problem with this alpha game is that it crashes on almost everyone
recommended: and a LOT! but it does not matter that much
hoursPlayed: it's only an alpha after all.\n\nso to be an alpha

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nthere is no way to describe this game other then pure gold. How many games have you played where you get to be a giant kung fu Rabbit beating the everloving ♥♥♥♥ out of other kung fu rabbits. and you dont even have to be a rabbit. you have an assortment of other kung fu animals you could be. Such as a naked rabbit, dog, cat, or wolf. And if you ever wanted to be master splinter theere's rats too. The game play is also quite intagrative with how combat works and even with free climbing. overall you' have countless hours of fun on this game I cant wait until theres a full campain.
